RAW: During the deep trenches and darkness of my addiction, my reward was my drug. The reward was usually an immediate one, as I was able to completely numb myself from the feelings, thoughts, people, and situations around me that caused my inner, unbearable pain. The problem, though, Was that I had created a severely unhealthy reward system……one that Reminds me of a Never-ending carousel ride, having my disease as the entity in charge of the controls. As the ride slowed down one day, I was able to jump off…to escape.   The once Dreadful carousel that I was on is no longer existent. Today I am in charge of the ride that I take. I am in charge of my actions and my decisions. Most importantly I am in charge of my abstinence and my road to recovery. The reward system I have built today  Provides me with the encouragement. This encouragement fuels my sobriety. Everyday that I go without using me reward myself with looking in the mirror and telling myself what a genuinely good and selfless human being me am. I deserve to be rewarded for each milestone I reach because this cunning disease is relentless. For my personal accomplishments during my recovery, I reward myself with a trip to the movies, or dinner with friends.   Today I am able to do things that embrace relaxation, and these moments of meditation, are the Rewards that I deserve, look forward to, and love.
CATS: ABSTINENCE,SELF ESTEEM / deserve & rewards
WELLGOS: Abstainer Amazer,Inner Power Allower,Self Esteem Elixir,Sober Selfie

RAW: I’m scared. I’m nervous. I’m out of my element. But I’m here for my recovery. My only requirement for membership of these groups is to have the willingness and strength to stop using. My first meeting — I made it! I am proud of myself for taking this gigantic step towards my recovery. I have the ability to change. The desire to change. And these meetings and groups help me make this change a reality.
CATS: FEAR,COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,BABY STEPS / Help & support,CHANGE / courage
WELLGOS: Fear Flusher,Braverade,Progress Pollinator,Ever Evolving Flower

RAW: What safeguards my sobriety? My courage. My honesty. My willingness to admit that I am powerless over my addiction. I realize that remaining clean and sober is hard work. But I also realize that juggling all the problems caused by using is even harder work. The fact is, temptations will never really go away. And what safeguards me is my awareness of this fact. Today I am able to acknowledge that my best decisions in my past got me to where I am today. I have no intention of returning to that dark place, where temptations ruled over me. Today these realizations enable me to stay focused on my recovery. To remain clean and sober, I am able to change all people, places, and things. These are my safeguards for sobriety. The thought of living the rest of my life sober sounds like a terrifying and impossible feat. But I don’t have to ponder the rest of my life. I can live in this moment, this hour this day. Just for today. Trying to control things I can’t control is a threat to my sobriety. I am as dedicated to my recovery twice as much as I was dedicated to getting high. (Dedication doubler) This dedication is safeguarding my sobriety.
CATS: POWERLESSNESS,SOBRIETY / maintaining & will power,SELF ESTEEM / courage,TRUTH / Admit addiction
WELLGOS: Power Shower,Sobriety Soulmater,Deep Down Diver

RAW: The most powerful force of nature seems like denial. I wake up every morning and look in the mirror. I see the eyes of addiction, lips of addiction, a body of addiction. But my courage to confess is motivational. I am no longer ashamed. I am free in my honesty. Free to love myself for who I am and addiction is a part of me. I will never look down on myself 4 having this illness. I accept who I am, therefore, I accept that I am a recovering addict. I am becoming someone who loves themselves, every single part. Facing my addiction includes feeling emotions I use to cover up. Today I am willing to face these fears. Looking my addiction right in the eye has the potential to expose some frightening realizations. But I am ready. Today I am strong.The very first step is admitting to myself that I am powerless over it. By admitting this, I know that drugs/alcohol never worked for me, and they are no longer a part of my life. I understand their power and I am worthy of change. Today I say goodbye to all people, places, or things that threaten my sobriety.
CATS: INNER POWER / Vulnerability,CONFESSION / powerlessness,WORTHINESS / self love & acceptance,FREEDOM / past & let go
WELLGOS: Braverade,Inner Freedom Forager,Addiction AMF’r,The Dynamotivator,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Admit addiction

RAW: Rather than use when I have the urge, I am now shifting gears. exploring healthy alternatives that support my recovery. Going to a support group meeting is a great way to explore my alternatives to drugs/alcohol/ getting high. I am open to receiving this help. I am tempted to use, and intend on reaching out to others that share this same illness. My alternative to using is to listen to people who have more recovery than I do. Exploring my alternative allows me to explore other ways to cope with my temptations. When I reach out to others in recovery, I feel powerful, supported, understood and capable of staying clean. I know that alternatives exist when it comes to my addictions. Today I see myself exploring healthy, beneficial ones.
CATS: BEHAVIOR,HABITS,COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,URGES / support & help,PROGRESS / start small
WELLGOS: Growth Gardener,Bad Habit Butcher,Urge Purger,Journey Jazzer,New Pattern Painter / confidence & awareness

RAW: Well, when I receive bad news, I — I realize this news is bad, but I refuse to grant it that much power, as it consumes me and affects my sobriety. My perception of this news does not have to be bad or negative. I trust my inner wisdom and intuition. Today I accept that receiving bad news is a part of life, but I am not allowing those things have power over my life. I am ultimately in control of how I react. Some feelings simply cannot be avoided, especially when hearing something that is shocking, scary or even devastating. How I respond to these feelings is critical to my recovery, and no matter what news I receive, it is not strong enough to overcome my willingness to stay sober.
CATS: INNER POWER,REACTIONS,INNER POWER / Self control & willpower
WELLGOS: Stress Striker,Worry Washer,Soul Controller,Reactions Auditor,Manic Massager

RAW: I now hold the power to plan for recovery by anticipating and acknowledging my triggers. I will face battles, but these will not weigh me down and deter my recovery. I will never revert back to throwing in the towel and succumbing to this disease. Inspiration is flowing through every cell in my body, and I am continuously developing new strategies to prepare for these battles, because in the end, I am winning the war on addiction. I realize that it is difficult and confusing to manage my recovery sometimes, but I'm learning more and more about it and doing my best.
CATS: TRIGGERS / awareness,INNER POWER / Tools,CHANGE / courage
WELLGOS: Inner Power Allower,Abstainer Amazer,Trigger X’r,Mighty Motor Cranker,Fear Dancer

RAW: I recognize that I have shifted the blame on my loved ones, blaming them for my using. Today I know that I only have myself to blame for my actions. Shifting the blame on others will result in a threat to my recovery because I am allowing myself to play a victim when I am a victim no longer. When I take responsibility I am embracing my power. Today I will not take on this toxic mindset. My peace of mind is within my ability to take responsibility for everything that is within my power to control and to change. Shifting the blame on others use to be part of my daily thoughts; however, today I don’t shift the blame, and I choose to take accountability.
CATS: BLAME,RESPONSIBILITY,AMENDS,RECONCILIATON,ACCOUNTABILITY / De-blame
WELLGOS: Victim Vanquisher,Blame Changer,The Deblamer,Responsibility Rippler

WELLGOS: Power Pooper,Brain Unchainer,Mentality Mender,NeuroTuner,Belief Superseder

These bridges are leading me to a newfound success and feelings that drive me to continue on my path of recovery. Building new Bridges is an incredible experience, and some are still a work in progress. I rely on these bridges to provide a safe, promising path of recovery and abstinence.

WELLGOS: Brick Wall Snowballer,Sobriety 101'r,Void Avoider,WAIT AND SWITCH / Progress

I forgive myself for the things that I have done in my past and the people I have hurt, and each step I take in this direction is enabling me to build new Bridges in their place.

WELLGOS: Sobriety SOS’r,Inner Forgiverizer,Progress Pollinator,Soul Surgeon,Inner Freedom Forager

RAW: When I used drugs, I was alone and I preferred to be alone. Now I know that this was unhealthy. I need friends, especially ones in recovery. Today I open myself up to establish these new connections and new friendships, and my story and journey through my recovery is an inspiration to others. Today, I am my best friend. I am beginning to love myself for my faults and successes. I need a support group that supports my recovery, especially for calling me out on my crap. I don’t need my circle of friends to agree with me, I just need them to be honest with me. Going to a meeting tonight is allowing me to meet another person I can relate to.

WELLGOS: Sobriety Soulmater,Progress Pollinator,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive,VULNERABILITY / listen to others

RAW: Change is uncomfortable, but I am working through it and remembering to just breathe through every second. Today in my recovery embrace all the changes that are supportive of my recovery. Not only do I embrace the changes but I also embrace the challenges that come along with each one. Today I cannot run from my fears. If I fear change, I see myself relapsing. When first sober, I was on what they refer to as “the pink cloud”. I was gung ho, motivated and ready for the rest of my life to begin. After a while, I realized my motivations changed and were not as exciting as they were. Because of this, I am always open to receiving new elements for change and challenge myself to make a personal inventory.

WELLGOS: Pink Cloud Clinger,Challenge Ninja,Inner Motor Motivator,Adversity Adventurer

RAW: Controlling my compulsions seems to put them in a pressure cooker, and fuels the compulsive cycle even more. Today, I can’t just control them by suppressing them, I am allowing myself to replace my compulsions with new behaviors and responses. In order to replace them, I am first changing my system of beliefs. My eyes are on the prize and I know how to listen to my compulsions. I believe they are teaching me exactly what I require to change.
CATS: BELIEFS,REACTIONS,CRAVINGS / vulnerability & learning
WELLGOS: Compulsion KO’r,Belief Superseder,Responsibility Rebooter,Growth Gardener,Mentality Mender

RAW: I  honestly use to think that I couldn’t deal with certain conflicts without drugs. Now I realize that I actually was never dealing with anything, just suppressing the feelings. Avoiding conflict 2 keep the peace around me will only lead to unleashing a war Within Myself. While it’s okay to not fear conflict I am still very aware that using new coping skills are my best means of approaching situations that carry stress and unhealthy emotions. Today I have the strength and courage to know the difference in determining which conflicts I can face. I must not avoid conflict. This is what fed my addiction was avoiding the pain connected with the conflict. Today, I am learning to constructively deal with hardships and work through them

I face my addiction and temptations one day at a time and I do the same with my cravings, one at a time

RAW: I  am up against many odds, but my hope and urge to stay sober enables me to break temptation and drug related cycles that fed my bad habits. I began to break my personal cycle of addiction and temptation when I chose to admit that I am powerless over my disease. That was my first step towards recovery. Taking an inventory of myself enables me to magnify the unhealthy Cycles which led me down a dark road in the past. Reviewing bypass is a critical part of my present and my future. No matter how shameful or embarrassing my actions were, today I use them in my favor, as they allow me to clearly see what behaviors and repeated tendencies held me back from being the strong, sober, and inspiring person I am now. My cycle of addiction is both transparent and nontransparent. To break the cycles within my own addiction requires a focus on what I can see and what I can’t. I have already begun to break my drug-related (using) cycles. Today I am clean and sober, and one day clean is just as important as a million days.

WELLGOS: Symbolic Stepper,Power Shower,New Pattern Painter / grit & progress,I-examiner - reactions & behavior,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Inventory

RAW: Confessing to the damage I have created is ever-growing. When I was in the midst of using, I was engulfed in a selfish lifestyle. Confessing to the damage is monumental to my recovery. Today I choose to participate in confessing my damages. It's time that take a moment now and confess my past behaviors that hurt myself and those around me. I am accountable for these damages and by confessing them I am healing my own guilt and raising my own self- worth and self-esteem. If I ignore them, I am ignoring a part of this disease that thrives in chaos and guilt. I am guilt ridden from emotional damage I have left on others. They have chosen to forgive me because they see the changes I am making and the ownership I am taking.

It is important to delay some desires. Falling victim to them will land me back in the midst of my temptations and I am no longer this person. RAW: During the deep trenches and darkness of my addiction, my reward was my drug. The reward was usually an immediate one, as I was able to completely numb myself from the feelings, thoughts, people, and situations around me that caused my inner, unbearable pain. The problem, though, Was that I had created a severely unhealthy reward system......one that Reminds me of a Never-ending carousel ride, having my disease as the entity in charge of the controls. As the ride slowed down one day, I was able to jump off...to escape. The once Dreadful carousel that I was on is no longer existent. Today I am in charge of the ride that I take. I am in charge of my actions and my decisions. Most importantly I am in charge of my abstinence and my road to recovery. The reward system I have built today Provides me with the encouragement. This encouragement fuels my sobriety. Every day that I go without using I reward myself with looking in the mirror and telling myself what a genuinely good and selfless human being I am. I deserve to be rewarded for each milestone I reach because this cunning disease is relentless. For my personal accomplishments during my recovery, I reward myself with a trip to the movies, or dinner with friends. Today I am able to do things that embrace relaxation, and these moments of meditation, are the Rewards that I deserve, look forward to, and love.
CATS: DEMONS,ABSTINENCE,MOTIVATION,WORTHINESS / deserve & rewards
WELLGOS: Demon Dethroner ,Abstainer Amazer,Worthy Soul’r,Inner Winner,Journey Jazzer

RAW: I’ve always heard that the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over and over but expecting different results. This definition models what my life was like in the midst of my addiction. Today, though, these sick, unhealthy behaviors have been diminished through pure dedication to my recovery and hard work. I rid myself of the behaviors that are compulsive and unhealthy and I am able to achieve this because I now see how each action and decision will impact my life. Instead of using drugs when feeling anxious, to suppress ill feelings, to avoid withdrawals, or simply because I had taught myself that it was ok, I now choose to only engage in things that support my sobriety and my plan to remain sober. These types of healthy behaviors save me from my own destruction, and they rescue me from an insurmountable amount of pain and suffering that are buried in using drugs and alcohol.
CATS: COMMITMENTS,GROWTH / behavior & habits,FREEDOM / tools & strategies,SOBRIETY / behavior & action
WELLGOS: Behavior Savior,Insanity SOS’r,Illogical Looper,The Dynamotivator,Mighty Motor Cranker,COMMITMENT knitter / abstinence confidence

RAW: The repetitive, drug seeking, and withdrawal avoiding part of my past can be defined as the severe depths of hell. If there is a hell, the moments, hours, and days of relentless, excruciating physical and mental withdrawal would be my hell. These moments, though, I do not cover up and try to forget. I use them as a means of staying sober, always reminding me of the benefits of being sober. I never want to return to that awful, horrid, lonely place, and it is those very experiences that pull back the covers, revealing the beauty of sobriety. I cannot change the past, nor do I wish to. It is why I am who I am today—a beautiful person in recovery and grateful for what I have experienced, what I am currently experiencing, and the experiences that are yet to come.
CATS: DEMONS,PAST,GROWTH / learning & mistakes,GRATITUDE / opportunities
WELLGOS: Demon Greeter,Gratitude Grower,Killer Kickstarter,Addiction AMF’r

RAW: My disease of addiction was fueled by blame. During these hopeless days, nothing was EVER my fault. I actually have a particular word that I revert to when reminding myself of ditching the blame or excuses, as I now know that one of my jobs within my sobriety is to be a part of the solution, not the problem, and only take ownership for the things I have the power in changing....its called PRIDE, P for Personal, R for Responsibility, I for IN, D for DELIVERING, and E for EXCELLENCE. So, it is my personal responsibility in delivering excellence. I do not blame myself because I am a recovering addict, nor do I blame my actions on my addiction. I chose to ditch ANY blame, whether it’s external or internal because I know that even when I make mistakes, it still means I am trying. So long as I own my own feelings and take responsibility for my own actions, the blame game will never surface simply because I choose my own destiny. Rather than avoiding the problem or blaming it on a person place or thing, I choose to peel back the layers until I reach the root of the problem. These steps enable me to talk blame out the window and never look back.
CATS: BLAME,RESPONSIBILITY,ACCOUNTABILITY / De-blame
WELLGOS: Responsibility Rippler,The Deblamer,Soul Controller,ADMIT / accountability

RAW: When I think about what my body and brain have endured during my past drug use, I am so amazed and astonished at how far I have come, physically and mentally. Being sober has definitely provided me a new beginning and a new lease on life. It is important though for me to acknowledge and understand and accept that being sober and being in recovery does not eliminate stressors and elements that life brings my way. I am aware that my recovery is dependent on how I view things and my perception of my capabilities. There have been times where I’ve noticed that those thoughts lead to feelings of stress, sadness, anger and so on. It is in these moments, when these dark, negative thoughts begin to settle in that I use the most important tools that I have been given.....a positive outlook and elevated sense of self-worth. There will be times in the future that similar situations will present themselves that cause chaos or I will have to handle stressful dilemmas. It is my witness of these situations that makes me strong. These negative thoughts will not lead two negative beliefs and actions such as using or relapse because I can replace and redirect them with brighter, healthier thoughts. It is also incredibly important for me to understand and believe that what I put into my body has both long-term and short-term effects on it. Today I am able to brighten my own brain with the proper diet and I’m able to give my physical self the gift of exercise and participating in events that are conducive to my recovery. My goal is to wake up every morning and live a life of sobriety. One way I can achieve this is continuing to provide myself with the best possible platform to reach my daily goal. Whether it’s the foods I’m eating or the amount of exercise I’m completing, or the positive list of the people places and things around me, they all have the potential to brighten my life, and more specifically, to rid of the elements that overshadow my progress as a recovering addict.

RAW: I am turning into a person that I have previously described AZ someone that I would look up to and someone that portrays the qualities of a hero. I am in control of my life because I am in control of my decisions. These decisions are not overshadowed and held captive by drugs or alcohol no longer. I am becoming someone who loves themselves for my faults and successes. This newfound love and acceptance is nothing short a blessing. I owe it to myself to cut myself some slack because I have done a tremendous amount of work to get to the place in my life where I am today. Today I am a changed person and even though there are many to give credit to that have stood by me and offered support, at the end of the day, the biggest amount of credit goes to myself for making things happen, and changing who I used to be.

WELLGOS: The Blessifier,Inner Greatness Greeter,Gratitude Goosebumper,Self Esteem Elixir,Ever Evolving Flower

RAW: I have come to realize that change is not always easy. For example, changing the very things that supported the addict or alcoholic I used to be was sometimes difficult. I have found that change is difficult because there’s not just one layer. Recovering from addiction includes changing all people places and things that are a threat to my recovery and leaving such people, places, and things behind is hard, painful, and leaves me feeling vulnerable. It is during these times that I choose not to get stuck in the sinking quicksand of addiction. I keep chiseling away, no matter how raw or vulnerable it feels. Establishing new friendships takes a great deal of trust but today I have trust in this process because I know that those who are drug and alcohol free are those who will lead me down the road to recovery. I have faults and weaknesses, and these require constant observation, attention, and change. When I feel vulnerable, I look to others who have been in this position. It is during these moments that they walk me out of the quicksand by offering their own experiences. Through these experiences I gather continuous hope that I am capable of overcoming those moments of vulnerability without using drugs or alcohol to numb the exposure of these layers.
CATS: INNER / SELF / Inventory,CHANGE / self love & true self,VULNERABILITY / others who’ve been there
WELLGOS: Deep Down Diver,Hope Harvester,VULNERABILITY / mistakes & learning,RAW SOUL REVEALER / trust others

RAW: My motivation for change traces all the way back to where my addiction began. My motivation for change exist in those deep dark moments of Silence waiting for that drug to kick in and numb my pain. My motivation for change lives and breathes in those moments of despair and physical and mental withdrawal. Yes I have had some incredibly frightening, sad, and depressing experiences, and these very experiences I use as fuel for my sobriety and abstinence from drugs today. I am not going back to those dark places. I’m not going to put myself in a position of being in withdrawal from drugs. In order to be within the withdrawal process this means I would have to pick up and use. Today I choose sobriety. Today I am strong and am proud to choose another route, even if it is not physically or mentally comfortable at the time. My feelings and emotions were meant to be felt, not smothered. I have faith that even though the emotions and feelings I experience are uncomfortable. I know they are what makes me human. Today I am motivated to change because I am motivated to feel.
CATS: EMOTIONS,CHANGE / motivations,MINDSET / no matter what
WELLGOS: Emotions X-rayer,Feelings Fantasizer,Killer Kickstarter,The Dynamotivator

RAW: One of the core components of my being is my willpower. My willpower is much like a wall. This wall has a number of bricks that include self-esteem self-efficacy self-motivation self confidence in self-worth. Each of these bricks are needed to create a strong durable wall of willpower and if one is lacking than the other ones suffer.. I have the willpower to achieve anything that I set my mind to. Quitting cold turkey requires this strong mindset. No I have no doubts that my willpower can lead me to a road of recovery, I know that quitting cold turkey may not be the healthiest route to choose. There’s a lot of change that comes with absence from drugs. This type of change is social physical emotional and mental and in order to give myself the best chance at sobriety modify quitting cold turkey, changing it to a warm turkey. I am ultimately in control of my decisions and behaviors and because I’m worth living a life free of alcohol and drugs I choose to get help and assistance from every resource around me. The thing is that I do not always know what’s best for me. What’s best for me is a collective decision and thought process that consist of the most effective plan for me. I tend to look at it like this. Cold turkey is the fastest and quickest route to take but not the healthiest and safest. It’s like standing on top of a building obviously the quickest way down is to jump. With this and now he and mind quitting cold turkey is very similar in nature because jumping would be detrimental.
CATS: ABSTINENCE,MINDSET / will power,SOBRIETY / maintaining & will power
WELLGOS: Cold Turkey Taster,Sobriety 101'r,The Momentumizer ,WAIT AND SWITCH / Progress

RAW: Cravings or something that will always exist. Some are foreseen, while others are not and either way these cravings have a tendency to cramp my experiences in recovery. It is how I react to these Cravings that is important. The amount of power a craving has depends on the amount of power I get to it. For instance I have physical urges that are screaming 4 the numbing sensation that my drug of choice provided. Over time these physical urges subside and I am strong enough to wait them out. Either urges manifest from cravings that are triggered within my social or environmental setting. Today I have the choice to walk away and remove myself from the situation which and immediately decreases the power of a craving. I also have learned to accept my cravings for what they are and by understanding why they exist and where they’re coming from I Empower myself gaining the strength to fight each craving. Cravings that have the potential to cramp my life are easily torn down Buy replacing them with healthy thoughts or activities. When a craving emerges I simply revert to a thot or an exercise to take its place until it passes. Cravings are temporary and manageable. I consistently work towards setting myself up four success by using all the coping strategies I have learned.

WELLGOS: Reactions Auditor,Craver Saver / Braver,I-Can-ographer,Self Control 101'r,I-examiner - reactions & behavior

No matter which type of craving arises I have devised a healthy plan 2 crash each one. I do not allow these to trigger drug use. First, I know that I have the potential to set myself up for their arrival by not taking care of myself...getting enough sleep, eating properly, and putting myself in questionable social scenarios. I am surrounded by loving caring individuals who are here to help me through this journey because I don’t have to walk through it alone.

Today I feel my feelings and even though some are more difficult than others I know a craving and an urge are temporary and they too shall pass.

No matter what my day is like or how many things I have on a list to do within that day, my recovery comes first and I always make time to care for myself. My body deserves to be rested, and given what I have put it through in the past, this rest serves as a time of healing from all the toxins that I held onto for so long.

RAW: Feeling angry, nervous, scared, or anxious are all unpleasant and uncomfortable. There are definite moments I need to take the edge off; however, drugs and numbing is no long a choice. I accept that all of these emotions will happen at some point, and when these points arise, I am able to take the edge off by taking a well-deserved break from that moment. Weather it’s a nap or simply peace and quiet, these offerings feel so much better for taking the edge off. Most importantly, I look back at what I accomplished and praise my own decisions and self-worth because the edge offer I chose, enabled me to take a step back from the ledge of using. I will never again take that detrimental leap.

RAW: Do I have excuses? ABSOLUTELY! Throughout my addiction excuses were embedded into every word I spoke and every thought process that passed through my mind. I used to tell myself that I can’t fathom going through physical withdrawals and I have to maintain by using. I used to tell myself that I was weak, and I was in this battle alone. WORDS AND THOUGHTS ARE POWERFUL...so powerful, they dictated my behavior and daily schedule of getting enough drugs to manage my cravings and suppress withdrawal day by day. Not today though. My excuses are just like my using drugs...they are nonexistent. Not only am I honest with everyone within my support system, but I am honest with myself and that was the first step I took two words living a life of sobriety. Any decision that I make that questions my sobriety or is causing me to take a step in the opposite direct, I intensely examine. For instance, there are support groups in meetings all around me at all times the day. These meetings and people are what’s best for me. If I find myself not attending these then I stop and examine the reason for my absence. I’m aware that my addiction is deeply rooted in both my conscience and unconscious mind. There’s a reason I’m not attending meetings then that reason is examined profusely. These very coping skills are those which lead me to life without drugs, day by day. I am no longer a victim nor do I revert to excuses that claim the role as one.

WELLGOS: Excuse Nuker,Responsibility 101’r,I-Examiner,Rationalization Rinser,ADMIT / Decisions & beliefs

One thing that I have realized is that excuses surface unconsciously. I easily dispose of the ones that are addiction driven by doing a self-review of each of my decisions, asking myself why I made this choice, and what is my overall hope to accomplish. Most importantly, I question my excuses by asking myself the most important question there is..... in any way shape or form, whether it be now or in the future, will this decision support my recovery?

Expect shit to happen, expect to go through life feeling the rawness of emotions. Having this expectation takes most of the power away from the element of surprise. So even though shit will happen, it will feel like you are literally learning how to walk again, at least you are able to take a step in the right direction....at least you are able to take a step...period.

RAW: Feeling happy is something that I adore. There’s actually a physiological reason why happiness and gratification feel good. My brain releases endorphins, and these endorphins serve as a natural high. Today, I don’t have to experience pleasure constantly, as I know that if I chase these feelings; this is only fueling poor impulse control. Delaying gratification and pleasures only continue to make me a stronger person in recovery. Yes, I’d much rather experience pleasure than pain, but this is unrealistic. Delaying my gratification enhances my self-control. Being unable to resist feelings of constant and immediate happiness puts my recovery first. While it’s completely healthy for me to live in the moment, it’s more wise and healthier to prepare for the future about planting the seeds now that I can depend on in the years to come.

RAW: When my addiction was in Full Tilt I simply never gave any thought to the consequence for long-term effects of my decisions. This sums up a lack of impulse control. During each day of recovery one of my main goals is to be brutally honest with myself. To accomplish this it is important for me to continuously recognize that even though my addiction is in remission my impulses are not. Today, though, even though they exist, it is incredibly empowering to not only accept their existence, but also to raise doubts on their true worth. You see, it is not the impulses that hold all the power, it is how we value them. I am constantly impeaching these impulses. Think about this for a second....why should an impulse, one that is generated from such a cunning, selfish disease be given power over my actions and consequences? Today I’m stronger than that. It is only common sense and true unconditional love for myself that I easily raise doubt on these impulses given their origin. No longer do these impulses impeach my life as a whole, as the emotions and feelings that embrace them only derive from the deepest and darkest depths of addiction. They are untrustworthy, they are invalid, and they no longer have any level of power that influence my decision making process.

WELLGOS: Bitter Truth Taster,Compulsion KO’r,I-examiner - motivations,Self awareness / confidence to admit,ADMIT / Decisions & beliefs,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Face truths

RAW: I am fully capable of lessening any form if drug relapse. Reducing or lessening relapse lies in a number of strategies that I continuously embrace. With every free moment, I have I choose to attend meetings self-help groups or read, testimonials, or scientific studies pertaining to this cunning disease. Knowledge is power and the more I learn about this illness, the more prepared I am for what to expect. Being aware of my own individual symptoms is a key part of my lessening strategies. For instance, sometimes I am able to determine that I am putting myself in risk of relapse because my stress levels are heightened. Using effective coping strategies that include the love and support of my family and social network, and love and support for myself, as I am my biggest cheerleader. Sometimes it is as simple as looking in a mirror and telling myself how proud I am to be who I am. I know that it is not supportive to my recovery to stay out late at night with friends, nor is it healthy to tell myself that I deserve to have a drink for all the days I’ve been sober. In fact, it’s just the opposite. I deserve not to have a drink and not to use, and that is the most precious gift I can give myself. Self-awareness is my key to lessening relapse.

WELLGOS: Lapse Lessenizer,Worthy Soul’r,I-Can-ographer,Self awareness / confidence to admit,SELF HARM / Tools

RAW: Once experiencing a relapse there are so many things that I’m able to take away from this situation too to avoid another one occurring. I’m able to point out key factors that have contributed to the strength and capacity of using and relapsing, stress building from various situations is a red flag. I have learned valuable lessons from ignoring past stressors. They are like volcanos, brewing and boiling and awaiting to explode. Ignoring them is simply the unhealthiest way to cope. I’ve learned that an onset of depressive feelings, isolating others, elevated nervousness, a decreased need for sleep, shifting moods, drastic change in energy levels, feeling easily discouraged and unable to concentrate are all important realizations for my recovery. I have learned priceless lessons from each, and by speaking with others close to me, I’m able to keep an open dialogue to be called out on any of these warning signs resurfacing or emerging.

WELLGOS: Lapse Lessonizer,Little Hint Listener,Self Harm Alarmer,Inner Eye Opener,Ill Feelings Illuminator,SELF HARM / Self honesty & admit

RAW: I have negative thoughts. I’m human. Its how much worth and value I place on these thoughts and how I respond to them that is critical to my sobriety. The fact is, life gets hard, and recovery is no different. I don’t live in a bubble protected from the outside world and all its evils. Bad things happen to good people. These bad things do not control me, though. I am in control because I have blessed myself with one of the most beautiful gifts imaginable....self- worth and forgiveness. Just as quick as the negative thoughts appear, they pass. If they re- emerge, I know that there’s something that I need to work on, change, or alter. For example a lot of my friends are able to go out and have dinner and have a few glasses of wine or a few beers. I have accepted that I cannot and will not take part in these situations because I suffer from a disease that will kill me if I feed it these substances. Does it suck? ABSOLUTELY! BUT, what sucks more is the thought of having my family plan my own funeral. Thoughts are just that...they are thoughts. I don’t have to like and be happy with everything. I love and am happy with myself, and that’s more than enough to knock any negative thoughts to the curb.

My personal urges have no ground to stand on simply because I have consistently replaced them with ongoing recovery and abstinence from drugs and any mind-altering substances. When I hear the term erode, I think of the earth and its ever-changing shape stemming from the natural elements that wear on it. My recovery is much like the water in a stream. It is constantly moving forward, it is powerful, and it removes everything in its path.
CATS: SOBRIETY / celebrate & progress,URGES / tools & techniques,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future,INNER POWER / Self control & willpower
WELLGOS: Urge X’r,New Pattern Painter / confidence & awareness,Inner Motor Motivator,Compulsion KO’r,The Momentumizer

RAW: Throughout my drinking career, instant gratification was the norm. I wanted what I wanted, and I wanted it all, right now! I have learned that almost everything I do comes in baby steps. I have to remember that when I first learned how to walk, I didn’t just wake up one day and walk perfectly, it took time. Now, as I work towards goals, taking baby steps is okay with me, for a couple of reasons. Firstly, baby steps slow me down and give me time to decide if my course of action is really what I want. Secondly, by slowing down and being deliberate, I can better master what I’m doing – instead of being a jack of all trades, master of none, I can be a master of what I set my mind to doing.

RAW: I tried to control every aspect of my life. When things didn’t go my way, in a conversation, project, etc., I would apply a liberal amount of my willpower to make things go my way. The harder I pushed, the worse things got. By not trying to control everything and realizing what I should and shouldn’t try even attempt to, life has gotten so much easier. Letting go of control and brought a certain level of serenity to my life. Being the stage manager sucks and I never want to do it again.

WELLGOS: Controller Coaster,Should Shover,Serenity Simulator,Mistruster Duster,Powerholic Healer,Inner Freedom Forager

RAW: Thinking about drinking – the taste and feel – made me salivate as if I were a starving man looking at a perfectly cooked steak. At that point, nothing else mattered. While I still have the occasional thirst, I replace alcohol with something that has a little bite to it like adding pure lemon juice to ice water. Like a smoker, I get the same cup tipping motion and harsh sensation without all the gnarly side effects.

WELLGOS: Pattern Interrupter,New Pattern Painter,Craver Saver / Braver,SELF HARM / Tools

I made bargains like drinking only beer or limiting the amount I would purchase, in some insane delusion that it would be different this time. When I have those idiotic glimpses of insanity now, I stop whatever it is I’m doing and recall all the things that went wrong when I lied to myself like that. I know when I am fooling myself, I just admit it better these days.

Any delusion is possible when lubricated with alcohol. It’s hard to drop the fake persona and be true to myself and others. My closest friends say they have always liked the real me and enjoyed seeing glimpses of it on occasion. Now I realize that my friends prefer to see me for who I am, and there was never any reason to hide it in the first place.

RAW: Resigned to the fact that being poor or homeless was what fate had in store for me, drinking didn’t seem to matter, so why not continue? Drinking made my poor lot in life more bearable. Now that I don’t drink, I’m no longer homeless, poor or without a future. My fate may be ultimately in God’s hands, but I know He wants me to do better, be better and have a purpose in life.

RAW: Alcohol was great for two things, suppressing my emotions and diarrhea of the mouth. I didn’t worry about my feelings as I couldn’t really feel them, and I obviously didn’t care about anyone else’s. To me, I presented “honest truths” to people without an ounce of my honest feelings to back them up. I have feelings today. I may not always like the feelings I have, but they are mine, and I get to face them and work through them instead of suppressing them. I am also more away of my actions or words and how they might impact someone else’s feelings. I’m gaining compassion for others, daily.

WELLGOS: Emotions Engineer,Feelings Fantasizer,Compassion Moonlighter,VULNERABILITY / share emotions

RAW: I’ve started more things than I can count and finished but a few. To say I was whimsical in my approach to doing things is an understatement. How disheartening it must have been for people to hear me say, “I promise.” I attribute my inability to finish things as part of my past need for instant gratification. I now finish what I start because of a heightened deliberacy in my actions. I first consider if it is something I truly want to pursue, then I take as many baby steps as necessary to get there.

Drinking beers and talking about how I would do it better if I were in their shoes. What a blessing it was to feel so superior to everyone else. Looking back, how much harm had I caused myself emotionally and spiritually by having a friend like this? I no longer keep friends like that. I prefer to have friends who lift me up when I’m down, not help me dive further down the rabbit hole of despair.

WELLGOS: Foul Weather Friender,Arrogance Arrestor,Pride Puffer,Ego X’r,Low Vibration Lifter,Bad Influence Bulldozer,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive

The outcome is better as is the satisfaction of a job well done.

I continue to distance myself from people, but only those that are unhealthy for me. I know what’s toxic for me, both interpersonally as well as situationally. I stay healthy by distancing myself from those who would do me harm, embracing those that don’t.

WELLGOS: Isolation SOS’r,Bad Influence Butcher,WAIT AND SWITCH / Emotions,SELF HARM ALARMER / distance from people

RAW: I did it; it was all me. Nobody or no thing had anything to do with it. Any good thing that came my way was based on my own merits. How is it possible I could have been so ungrateful, about so many things, for so long? My newfound vision and sense of gratitude makes me realize when a miracle happens, even if it’s a minor one. I am more blessed that I ever thought possible and the miracles happen every day. It’s a miracle I’m sober today. It was a miracle I was sober yesterday too. Every new day is a miracle in itself.

Sure, I still have bad moments, days, weeks, and months. But when I compare them to the misery that was my life before, they are so much more manageable. I have tools for living today and even though I can’t control some of the suck that comes my way, I now have the ability to work through it. I have a way out, and it doesn’t include embracing misery as a way of life. Misery is inevitable, not permanent.

RAW: I was obsessed with everything. I obsessed over drinking, having fun, pointing out the wrongs of people and the world I live in, and women. Anything and everything that caught my eye became an obsession, even if it only lasted a short while. Today, I am more moderate. I now have passions instead of obsessions. Sure, many things still catch my eye, but I now see them through the lens of being deliberate. If it doesn’t meet the criteria of what’s good for me, I try to rid my mind of it right away, lest it become an obsession.
CATS: INNER POWER / Self control & willpower,FREEDOM / tools & strategies,MINDSET / Clear headed
WELLGOS: Insanity SOS’r,Self awareness / habits & behavior,Inner Trash Trasher,Soul Controller

As I continue to change my life, and how I view it, I am creating a new second nature. My instincts have changed as have my reactions. It is now second nature to think before I speak; say yes (and mean it) when asked to do something and helping others. My second nature was never set it stone, and now that I know that, I can keep making positive changes to it.

WELLGOS: Pride Puffer,Ego Eclipser,Arrogance Arrestor,New Pattern Painter / confidence & awareness,Instinct Interrogator

I’m still ashamed of things I’ve done, but it helps to know that those things are in the past and they don’t represent who I am today. I no longer have to avoid people or stick my head in a bottle to get ‘over it.' Sure, I am still embarrassed by things I’ve done, but I can hold head up high knowing that’s not who I am anymore.

WELLGOS: Shame X’r,Ever Evolving Flower,Worthiness Whisperer,Inner Forgiverizer,RAW SOUL REVEALER / past mistakes,VULNERABILITY / connections

I can now look at life differently and see that nearly everything comes with a silver lining. People that irritate me are a gift from God, put in my path to teach me something, even if that something is tolerance. Problems I face in my career have become opportunities to better myself. If I fail, it’s not really failing; it is something I could learn from. Edison didn’t fail 10000 times to make a lasting lightbulb; he learned 10,000 ways how not to make a lightbulb.

RAW: How impulsive I was. I never had time to make plans; I was too busy figuring out ways to get high or drunk. I never made long-term plans because the future was always bleak, why bother. If I did make plans, I would simply wing it and hope for the best while expecting the worst. I’m more methodical in how I plan these days. I take other people into consideration and how what I do might affect them. I take the time to make sure my plan is aligned with what’s best for me, and my soul, in the long run. Planning is so much easier when I take my ego out of the equation.
CATS: PROGRESS / future & hope,MINDSET,GROWTH / supporting myself
WELLGOS: Values VIP’r,Soul Proprietor,Sobriety 101'r,WAIT AND SWITCH / Progress,COMMITMENT knitter / to others

RAW: I didn’t plan my day, alcohol did. Everything I did revolved around the next drink or drunk. Today I own it. I live for today. I have no control over the past, and I can’t let it control today. Today is all I have, so I better make the most of it.

WELLGOS: Past #2,The Mindfulizer,Regret Refunder,Self Control 101'r,Inner Freedom Forager

When I get an urge to do something, I can take a deep breath, relax and examine the possible outcomes of succumbing to an urge. Not all urges are bad, but at least I have to the tools to help me separate the good from the bad, and the downright stupid.

WELLGOS: Placid Reflux,Urge Auditor,Compulsion KO’r,Self awareness / habits & behavior,Reactions Auditor

Self-medication was my only hope. I still can’t sit still, but I have found ways to fill the time. I’ve reconnected with hobbies I thought long gone. Most important, I’ve found that there is always something to do or needing to be done. Staying active has gone a long ways in my sobriety, and I never want inactivity to rule my life again.

WELLGOS: Void Avoider,The Procrastina-shunner,Lazy Zapper,The Momentumizer ,New Pattern Painter / confidence & awareness

RAW: I didn’t just avoid the warning signs when I was drinking; I didn’t even see them. I realize now that I didn’t want to see them, and even if I did, my ego would get in the way a squash the thought. I don’t avoid warning signs anymore. They are an integral part of my life as I continue to seek out new ways of improvement. To me, warning signs almost always have a silver lining – they are a call to action. Warning signs are indicators that show me what part of me needs work.
CATS: GROWTH / learning & mistakes,SOBRIETY / behavior & action,WARNINGS / self aware & listen
WELLGOS: Sabotage SOS’r,Little Hint Listener,Inner Soul X-Rayer,SELF HARM / Warnings

RAW: When I was drinking, I thought I was pretty good at meditation and taking care of my soul. I would work on one tiny aspect of myself and call it good. How much more wrong could I have been? I now know that I don’t know much, and this applies to my soul more than anything else. I have come to believe that there is no such thing as a private thought without consequence. If I take the time to heal my soul, every other part of me seems to fall in line.
CATS: HEALING,GROWTH / true self,INNER / SELF / harmony & inner peace
WELLGOS: Whole Soul Healer,Serenity Soulmater,Inner Soul X-Rayer,Soul Surgeon,Spiritual Conquest-ador

RAW: I felt worthless. Even more troubling is that I thought that it was okay. In my sick mind, it made perfect sense to be worthless. At least I didn’t have to worry about sinking any lower. After years of hard work on improving my life, and my soul, I know beyond a shadow of a doubt I am good enough. I am worthy as a friend, a coworker or an acquaintance. My life matters because I am worth it. Worth every ounce of strength and effort I put into it. I am worthy of another’s affections and trust.
CATS: WORTHINESS / connections & sharing,VULNERABILITY / worthy,INNER / SELF / beliefs & insight
WELLGOS: Dead End Deluder,Worthiness Whisperer,Love Sweetener,RELATIONSHIPS / Trust & vulnerability,RAW SOUL REVEALER / worthiness

RAW: I remember the drip down the back of my throat. Every time I snorted painkillers--- it was a weird feeling that most people may not enjoy, it sort of reminds you of being sick, but that wasn’t the case for me. Before I get into the hype of the ritual process before I used, that sensation of the powder up my nose, and dripping down my throat instantly put me at ease. I smoked a cigarette right after, always, and really just wanted that to last forever. My entire body instantly felt relaxed, but I was also ready to take on the world. The only pain involved, for me, came later, and it was more emotion based. I never used a needle, (which helped justify my continued use), so the pain wasn’t noticeable physically, until I ran out of drugs and experienced withdrawals. The gratitude I felt using, after hours of withdrawal, was surreal. I rarely abused alcohol, because I loved drugs so much, but withdrawing was a different story. If I couldn’t find drugs, drowning myself in Jack Daniels seemed appropriate. But most of the time, alcohol limited the effects of the painkillers, so I often didn’t drink. These painkillers, or “blues,” also known as roxy’s, were my only solution, and my only problem. I couldn’t see anything beyond this pattern of getting and losing, getting and losing, because they felt so good. When I’d get blues, I had a very specific system of cutting them up, and organizing each line; it was like I was getting ready for hosting a party---the excitement of all the preparation for the main event. Except I was literally the only one going to this party, and after awhile, it did start to hurt---emotionally. When the happiness I received was greater from drugs than it was spending time with anyone I loved, it started to hurt. It started to hurt because everyone realized that before I even did. Then it really hurt. I kept using though. It was easier to numb guilt than face it. I had no courage at that point in my life, and often used excuses like, “well I’m not using a needle, so I must not be a drug addict.” Surely, these pills were legal somewhere, was a common thought. I never had a prescription for any of these pills, and obviously no appropriate evaluation for the occasional heroin use. It was when I stopped pills and went to heroin that my world really started moving in uncomfortable directions. It was always uncomfortable I’m sure, but when you do the one thing you said you’d NEVER do... it takes a toll. I never injected heroin but I did inhale it quite a bit. The smell of it wasn’t like the painkillers, and it grossed me out, but I became used to it after a few times. The drip feeling was still the same, only the feeling was much, much stronger.
CATS: POWERLESSNESS,DEMONS,CONFESSION / denial,TRUTH / dark past
WELLGOS: Guilt X’r,Excuse X’r,Pain Abstainer,Demon Doctor,Just One Justifier

RAW: There is a fear inside of me---I am beginning a new chapter of life without the use of drugs. But, by surrounding myself with positive people, and taking each day slowly, I remember my desire to stay clean is stronger than any fear I may possess. I was a little shy at first, but I met some good people at my first few meetings, who made me feel less alone. I am taking the steps to change my behaviors. Because my desire is strong, I am going to meetings regularly, even if intimidated, and even if my fears try to take over.I am staying in the day---focusing only on how to stay clean each day, and calling others through any struggles I face. The foundation on which I build my recovery is becoming stronger---I am building a strong network of people, and attending meetings regularly.
CATS: RESPONSIBILITY,BABY STEPS / Help & support,COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,PROGRESS / support
WELLGOS: Fear FYI’r,Sobriety SOS’r,Baby Step Embracer,Progress Painter,RELATIONSHIPS / Meetings & support,VULNERABILITY / connections

RAW: Safeguarding my sobriety is my priority, and the knowledge that putting anything before my recovery can mean losing my recovery. Staying in the day is crucial to maintaining my sobriety, because if I look ahead, I begin to wonder if I can stay sober forever. I take each day slowly, and focus on staying sober for that day, and that day, only. I listen to others, and receive advice. I do not put anything before my recovery because if I do, I run the risk of losing my recovery, and ultimately, whatever it was, I put in front of it! I stay away from old people, places, and things, and learn how to build new memories with new people at new places. Control is an illusion. When I remember how horrible my addiction was, and what kind of person I became, I no longer need to fantasize constantly about using, or if I can control it--- it was definitely worse than my life in sobriety. No matter how many problems I face clean and sober, I now possess the ability to work through them, something I didn’t have before. I also know my problems will only magnify if I use. Staying honest with myself, and at least one other person, is crucial to safeguarding my sobriety. Being willing to change, and to look at myself objectively, while difficult, is so important to maintaining my sobriety. Creating new habits is necessary----when I am triggered, my new thought process is to go to a meeting, or call someone, instead of using drugs.
CATS: CHANGE / action & behavior,VULNERABILITY / Show true self,GROWTH / willing to change,COMMUNITY / ask for assistance
WELLGOS: Values VIP’r,Bad Influence Bulldozer,New Pattern Painter / confidence & awareness,WAIT AND SWITCH / Progress,VULNERABILITY / listen to others

RAW: I am NOT my addiction. I respect its power, but I know it does not control me. It is strong, but I am stronger. With my newfound self-awareness and strength, I never have to live that way again. Knowing my powerlessness is freeing. I can no longer use successfully, so when I think about using, I remember it is not even an option if I want to live a happy life. I am not ashamed of my addiction, it is a part of me, but it also does not define me. Gaining clarity now, I can see that I do have the power to make changes in my life. I do what I need to do to maintain my sobriety. I do not keep old phone numbers, or go back to old places. I practice tough love when it comes to toxic past relationships. Fear will not take control over me, and when I feel like I have a desire to use, I will use my resources---I will call people in my network, and I will face my fears in healthy ways. I remain honest with myself, and others when I am struggling, and remember that I cannot do this alone.
CATS: INNER POWER,INNER MASTERY / strength,COMMUNITY / ask for assistance,INNER / SELF / awareness
WELLGOS: Addiction AMF’r,Inner Power Allower,Inner Winner,ADMIT / True self & vulnerability,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Admit addiction,VULNERABILITY / reach out for help

RAW: I was so blocked by feeling good from the drugs, no alternative seemed comparable to using. No goal, hobby, or past interest, held my attention anymore. When I found opiates, I felt like I found my soul mate, in some weird, twisted way. No other drug did it for me---it relaxed me, but also gave me confidence to be more social. But realistically, these drugs stripped, not only my personality, but my, soul away, and honestly, I forgot what my interests even were. Now, I begin exploring what makes me happy. As an active addict, many blind spots were present. Simply, I didn’t have the confidence to explore new things. I was too attached to my old ways because it’s all I knew for so long. When it came to the hardships of life, finding healthy alternatives wasn’t even on my radar. Today though, I am capable of relieving my stress in healthy ways, and finding healthy outlets to strengthen my foundation. In recovery, it is important that I have mental, emotional, and physical stimulation to combat any and all mental, emotional, and physical trauma I have endured in my addiction. Yoga, meditation, and other forms of exercise are crucial to maintaining my emotional, mental, and physical wellbeing. I would like to retrain my brain, so my first response to stress is to focus on a hobby, or, even explore new interests. The desire to use comes and goes, but by submerging myself in healthy alternatives, I always have something safe to do, or somewhere safe to go---I rarely feel on shaky ground.
CATS: FREEDOM / tools & strategies,CHANGE / action & behavior,PROGRESS / start small,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future
WELLGOS: Demon Dethroner ,The De-stress-calator,New Pattern Painter / confidence & awareness,Brain Unchainer,RAW SOUL REVEALER / emotions & urges

RAW: Through listening to others with experience in recovery, I gain more knowledge in the importance of changing my behavior over just simply apologizing to those I’ve hurt in addiction. It was told to me, that simply apologizing to those I’ve hurt isn’t much different than when I would apologize in active addiction. Every, “I’m sorry,” I ever said had no value to it, because I kept repeating my mistakes. No one took me seriously. I didn’t take me seriously. It is up to me now to actually change my behavior. I forgive myself for my actions in my past. I am strong, and I am not my mistakes. I can change. Listening to others, becoming aware of my flaws, allows me to know what needs to be changed about my unhealthy behaviors. Others who have more experience, will guide me to write my list of amends, and will assist me in taking the appropriate actions to physically make amends to those I have harmed. Each day, I will take note of my behavior, and avoid hurting people even in recovery.
CATS: AMENDS,CONFESSION / apology & forgiveness,ACCOUNTABILITY / Amends,COMMUNITY / listen to guidance
WELLGOS: Inner Forgiverizer,Amender Befriender,Relationship Redeemer,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Share & support,VULNERABILITY / listen to others,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / admit & amends

RAW: I used every single day, and it consumed me. Using was so commonplace for me that it became second nature. Eventually, I started crossing over the threshold of lazy behavior, to just really bad, bad behavior---becoming someone I did not recognize. Hitting bottom, I ended up asking for help. From there, I gained the willingness to change. Because of that, and repetition, recovery became more commonplace than using ever did. I attend meetings often, and get into a healthy, habitual routine. Meditation, and sitting with myself, gets me through my hard days, and eventually, through this repetition, and seeing results, seeing myself changing, these wellgorithms not only help me, but become second nature.
CATS: INNER POWER / Vulnerability,COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,CHANGE / motivations,GROWTH / supporting myself
WELLGOS: Bad Habit Butcher,New Pattern Painter / confidence & awareness,Behavior Savior,The Momentumizer ,Soul Survivor

RAW: When I received bad news in the past, my first instinct was to pick up a drug or drink. Pills, whiskey, and heroin were literally my only solutions. I had no working knowledge of acceptance in my life, no idea how to apply it, and taking the easy way out was, well, easier. Half of the reason why I used was because I never learned how to face life. But after awhile, avoiding life, became more painful than life itself. Now, with some clarity, and some positive people around me, I am able to accept life on life’s terms. Acceptance is my answer to all outside problems I face, and all inner struggles I face. It is through the practice of this acceptance, that I may become less affected by bad news, and more inclined to act positively when such bad news arises. Life is not happening to me, but often, happening for me. Lessons can be found in bad times, and I have gained the clarity now to see them. I prayed to see the truth once, regarding a romantic relationship. I didn’t know what I was doing, but someone told me to try it, so I did. Very soon after, I found out some extremely painful news about my significant other. While it was horrible, and ended our relationship, I realized the universe was taking care of me. It got me out of a toxic relationship, and changed my life exponentially. Now, when I get bad news, I remember that lesson, and acceptance comes much easier.
CATS: RESILIENCE / reaction & behavior,INNER MASTERY / perceptions,MINDSET / Perceptions
WELLGOS: Situation Unscrewer,Problem Primer,Blunder Blesser,Opportunity Oompher,Reactions Auditor,Hardship Hugger

RAW: Recovery arms me with tools---tools for dealing with life. The only “tool,” I had in addiction was numbing myself to the battles I faced each day. But the majority of the battles I was facing, I created myself. Using created so many problems---I stopped keeping my promises to people, I couldn’t deliver in school or in work. Using also made the problems I had even worse. If I had issues with my family, doing drugs only magnified them, and teared us apart even more. Now, I can see myself coming. I have gained enough self-awareness that I can stop myself in my tracks, before I act in self-destructive ways. I remember what it was like while using, especially when I listen to newcomers and their struggles. I do not want to go back to that life, so I constantly look at myself to avoid going backwards. Through continued work on myself, I know my triggers, and I know who I can and cannot spend my time with.
CATS: INNER MASTERY / tools & processes,CONFIDENCE / action & behavior,INNER / SELF / balance
WELLGOS: Self awareness / habits & behavior,Inner Winner,Obstacle Outfoxer,Behavior Savior,I-examiner - reactions & behavior,Motivation Moonbeamer

RAW: I have stopped the use of drugs. I have already achieved so much in that, and I am unwilling to let negative thoughts ruin what I have achieved. I am not perfect, but I am strong, and I am enough. Without drugs, I can live a beautiful life. Keeping a clean house is important. When I take care of myself, and put time into things I care about, like my home, bedroom, etc., I often feel better. When I treat myself with respect, and care about the things I own, I am unlikely to go backwards. This self-discipline yields self- respect and real results. I become confident, and happier. It is when I am self-conscious, and think I am not worth anything, that I revert back to old ways. I also keep my side of the street clean. In other words, relationships and maintaining them, has become important in my life. Acting in respectable ways with others, even if I disagree with them, keeps my self-confidence high, and reduces regret.
CATS: WORTHINESS / new life & future,CONFIDENCE / acceptance & worth,INNER MASTERY / self control
WELLGOS: Inner Power Allower,Negativity Nuker,THOUGHTS / positivity,Confidence Caffeinator,Self Worth Surfer,Values VIP’r,Abstainer Amazer

RAW: Self–loathing beliefs are what maintained my addiction, but they were only beliefs, not facts. When I begin to allow others to love me, when I am unable to love myself, that is when I feel most connected to truth, and less likely to believe false ideas. Being clean does not ensure my mental health all of the time---I still get crazy ideas, actually thinking I do not deserve good things! I acknowledge my negative beliefs, I talk about them, but I do not indulge in them. I used to believe I could not have fun in recovery because I needed some kind of drug or drink to have fun. Social gatherings to me meant lots of alcohol. I didn’t understand the concept of being social without heroin or whiskey to either numb me so I wasn’t scared to be myself, or to completely obliterate myself so I wouldn’t think about who I was becoming. Through new behaviors, new social experiences, and watching others stay clean and sober, I know that belief is not true, and my life can be very enjoyable without the use of substances.
CATS: WORTHINESS / connections & sharing,INNER POWER / Vulnerability,CHANGE / beliefs
WELLGOS: Love Sweetener,Belief Superseder,Growth Gardener,VULNERABILITY / mistakes & learning

RAW: I am accountable for my actions in addiction, and I am especially accountable for my actions in recovery. Resentments from my past allowed me to use without guilt. Now, without drugs clouding my mind, I realize I am the sole one to blame for my actions. And I begin to forgive myself. There was a time when I not only was unable to look at myself, but I didn’t know how to, and I didn’t have to. When I was upset about something, I just ran to painkillers or heroin. Because of my inability to look at myself, when something bad happened to me, it was easier for me to blame someone else. I was in so much pain that I was destroying my own life; it was easier to blame my family, or my friends, for ‘making me this way,’ thinking, ‘they caused this.’ Today, I look at myself. Today, I am accountable for my own actions.
CATS: CONFESSION / apology & forgiveness,ACCOUNTABILITY / Own up,VULNERABILITY / learning and mistakes,INNER / SELF / Inventory
WELLGOS: Inner Forgiverizer,Responsibility Rippler,Inner Soul X-Rayer,Blamenesia,VULNERABILITY / admit

RAW: I’m not sure if my brain ‘reboots’ itself necessarily, or if it has while I’ve been clean. But I think when I begin to act differently, my brain naturally follows, it naturally changes itself---a sort of, ‘bring the body, and the mind will follow,’ concept. And it works. Meetings have been helping in this process. I am powerless over my addiction, but I am not a victim. I do have the power to re-train myself, and get rid of my old ways.
CATS: INNER POWER / Self control & willpower,MINDSET / Future sobriety,CHANGE / mental confidence
WELLGOS: Brain Unchainer,I-Can-ographer,Inner Power Allower,New Pattern Painter,Bad Habit Butcher

RAW: I am continuing down the path of recovery, and making an honest effort to form new connections, and build more bridges. When I begin to feel shy, and cap myself off at the amount of connections I’ve made, that is when I stop learning, and short change myself. I acknowledge the personal growth that comes from building new connections. The love I receive from others is more than I could have asked for, and I continue to build and strengthen these bridges by giving them the attention they deserve.
CATS: GROWTH,INNER / SELF / balance,COMMUNITY / connection with others
WELLGOS: Love Sweetener,The Blessifier,Good Will Gardener,Kindness Karmifier,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,VULNERABILITY / connections

RAW: Some bridges have been burned because of my addiction, others, because of my sobriety, I will accept each situation fully, and realize my recovery is all that matters in this moment. In addiction, I hurt many people and burned many bridges, through lying, cheating, and stealing. The person I was in addiction was not someone anyone wanted to be around. But, I am not that person anymore, and my behavior is changing. People like me today. I like me today. In recovery, there are times when I need to burn bridges to protect my sobriety. I do not hang around people who are using. My life, and the people in it, all reflect what is conducive to a sober lifestyle.
CATS: INFLUENCES,CHANGE / self love & true self,AMENDS,RECONCILIATON,COMMUNITY / connection with others
WELLGOS: Amender Amen’r,Bad Influence Butcher,Sobriety Soulmater,Responsibility Rebooter,VULNERABILITY / connections

RAW: Building a strong foundation and a strong network is a high priority. I am learning to open myself up to others, and allow them to guide me through their own experience. Others lift me up when I cannot do it myself---because of recovery, I am no longer alone.
CATS: WORTHINESS / help,VULNERABILITY / Connection,COMMUNITY / listen to guidance
WELLGOS: Loneliness TLC’r,Low Vibration Lifter,VULNERABILITY / connections,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / support groups

RAW: Getting comfortable with the uncomfortable is so important, but it is not easy! Being uncomfortable sounds scarier, than it actually is. I can learn to be okay with being uncomfortable by experiencing it, instead of being too scared to experience it before I even can! There is so much growth in change. When I fight change, I do not grow. And when I do not grow, I become more vulnerable to use again. I embrace change today. I have learned that change is always taking place---around me, within me, and through my strong belief and trust that I am being taken care of by this universe, I embrace these changes willingly. I have found freedom in this new way of life, and change is essential so I do not go back into addiction.
CATS: FREEDOM / future & growth,CHANGE / courage,MINDSET / no matter what
WELLGOS: The Momentumizer ,Progress Painter,Adversity Ninja,Hurtle Hugger,New Pattern Painter / grit & progress

RAW: Compulsion is normal, but it doesn’t need to be unnerving. Through the routine of meetings, continuation communication with others, and meditation, I am less affected by these compulsions. Triggers come and go, but I found acceptance in knowing I cannot use successfully. My life becomes a prison cell, and that is just not worth giving up my newfound freedom.
CATS: FREEDOM / tools & strategies,TRIGGERS / confidence & strength,URGES / tools & techniques
WELLGOS: Trigger Transformer,Compulsion KO’r,Inner Freedom Forager,Motivation Moonbeamer ,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / support groups

RAW: I do not avoid conflict, but I do remain humble enough to know which situations to put myself in, and which I should not. I never faced conflict when using, I was always high---running from everything. Now, I know better, so I can do better. I avoid reacting, and I try responding----whether it be to a conflict, or to a combative individual. I keep my cool, and calm, and breathe through the tough feelings.
CATS: SOBRIETY / behavior & action,CONFLICT,REACTIONS
WELLGOS: Reactions Auditor,Conflict Connoisseur,Placid Reflux,Void Avoider,Self Control 101'r,I-examiner - reactions & behavior

RAW: I have so many new resources in recovery. When a conflict arises, or I am triggered by anger, or fear, I implement these new resources, such as meetings, and talking to my network I demonstrate what I know is true---feelings are not facts. I will get over this anger, and I do not need to react hostilely.
CATS: ANGER,CONFLICT,TRIGGERS / tools & techniques,RESILIENCE / reaction & behavior
WELLGOS: Behavior Savior,Anger Rinser,Feelings Felicitizer,frust,The Aggrava-shunner,Quarrel Quasher

RAW: Whenever I feel any doubt about my decision to stay clean, I remember how far I have come. There are so many people who are proud of me. I remember how strong and empowered I feel compared to active addiction. When I celebrate clean time at meetings, it sparks something inside me. It makes me feel not only apart of something, and not alone, but it also gives me the continued strength I need to stay clean. I love the relationships I have now. Past ones are getting better, and new, healthy ones, are forming.
CATS: GROWTH / motivation & boosts,GROWTH / proud,COMMUNITY / healthy relationships
WELLGOS: Inner Winner,Inner Light Illuminator,The Dynamotivator,Sober Selfie,Ever Evolving Flower,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive

RAW: I get in my own way, more than anyone, or anything, does. But there’s good news! There are ways I can save myself from myself! I do not have to act in old ways. I am becoming comfortable with change, because not changing may result in going backwards. I do not want to go backwards today. Change is good for my spirit. It makes me stronger, and more adaptable to life on life’s terms. I stay honest with my network. The call me out when I am acting in old ways. They help me from going backwards.
CATS: INNER POWER / Vulnerability,GROWTH / true self,COMMUNITY / listen to guidance
WELLGOS: Behavior Savior,Growth Gardener,Opportunity Oompher,VULNERABILITY / Radical self honesty

RAW: Active addiction robbed me of all the benefits life had to offer. Staying clean allows me to focus on the beauty in life I couldn’t see before. Staying clean has allowed me to participate in life! I no longer hide out in my home, hoping for change to come. I am the change. And now I can achieve the goals I could not while using. I had one responsibility while using---to get the next one. It held me back from everything. Now, with clarity, I have more confidence to go after what I was too scared to go after before.
CATS: SOBRIETY / costs & benefits,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future,CHANGE / motivations,MINDSET / Future sobriety
WELLGOS: Addiction AMF’r,Confidence Caffeinator,The Dynamotivator,Inner Light Illuminator,The Benefisher,Blessings Detector

RAW: Ditching the blame gave me an excuse to keep using. “It wasn’t my fault. Everybody else won’t leave me alone! If they would just leave me alone, I would be fine.” This veil of denial kept me sick. Ditching the blame was part of my addiction; it does not need to be part of my recovery. I used to blame others for my using. I used to blame life in general, for my using. I felt like the victim, and could not see why my life was not getting better. Becoming accountable in recovery opens the doors to freedom and inner change. I always benefit when I am honest. Recovery has given me the ability to get and stay honest.
CATS: BLAME,ACCOUNTABILITY / De-blame,TRUTH / self honesty
WELLGOS: Blamenesia,Responsibility 101’r,ADMIT / accountability,VULNERABILITY / admit

RAW: Addiction was filled with my lies. Constantly pretending. Constantly lying. Pretending I was fine. In sobriety, I am honest with where I am at in my recovery process. If I would like to talk the talk in meetings, it is important I am walking the walk in real life. I will not portray myself as one thing in front of others, and another behind closed doors. I can change today. I do not need to pretend I am anything I’m not.
CATS: CONFESSION / denial,VULNERABILITY / Show true self,INNER /SELF / true self
WELLGOS: Delusion Detector,Ego Eclipser,ADMIT / True self & vulnerability,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Face truths,VULNERABILITY / admit

RAW: I see new changes every day. I see them in the way I carry myself. I see them in my desire to stay clean. Meetings motivate me. The people I meet at meetings motivate me. But initially, I didn’t feel that way. I thought I had all of the answers, and I thought no one could help me. I was stuck in that old, arrogant mentality. When I started to realize that this mentality equated to my self- consciousness and ultimately, my using, I started to change my tune. These meetings facilitated that realization. My new habits are yielding positive results. I have stronger relationships with those I love, and that motivates me to keep the changes coming.
CATS: COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,GROWTH / motivation & boosts
WELLGOS: Inner Motor Motivator,Inner Guru Guarder,Ever Evolving Flower,VULNERABILITY / support from others,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / motivations

RAW: There were times while using that I did want to get clean, but I was too scared, “this is my fate,” I thought. I used to think, “if only I could start again, if only I could get a clean slate at life,” but I felt I had gone too far. After hitting bottom, running out of gas on the highway, and getting kicked out of my house, I realized I had no other option but to get clean if I wanted to keep living. After some time in the program, I understood that I was given another shot, a clean slate at life, and I was, and still am, grateful.
CATS: WORTHINESS / new life & future,GRATITUDE / opportunities,FREEDOM / future & growth,CHANGE / motivations
WELLGOS: Dead End Defier ,The Hopenotizer,Faith Flooder,NEW LIFE / POSSIBILITIES,The Blessifier,Opportunity Oompher

RAW: When I was using, I was fearful of quitting drugs. Drugs were all I knew. They didn’t talk back, they didn’t judge me; they were the only things I trusted. The ritual in itself---the cutting up and the snorting of painkillers, got me so excited. I was addicted to the process, just as much as the drug. The idea of quitting cold turkey was petrifying. Could I actually do it? But now... all of a sudden, I find myself doing it. I go to meetings. I listen. I stay in the day, and do not worry about staying clean tomorrow. I am staying clean today. It was scary to quit at first, and it can be a challenge on some days. But I have put so many different things between the drugs and myself; I do not fear going backwards.
CATS:
ABSTINENCE,COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,SOBRIETY / maintaining & will power,"WILL POWER
"
WELLGOS: Cold Turkey Taster,Scary Stepper,Self Control 101'r,New Pattern Painter / grit & progress,Fear Marshall

RAW: When I ran out of drugs, I had to get more. I could not control myself. Without opiates, I would get physically ill, and suffer major withdrawals. I do not have to live like that today. My behaviors are changing, and I am learning how to control myself. I may be powerless over drugs, but I am not powerless over my actions. I choose to change. I retrain my brain by changing my habits. I am not as inclined to act compulsively today. Acting compulsively is no longer attractive. My standards for myself are changing. The results from acting out rarely make me feel better, and my new habits give me more self-confidence. I speak to myself today. I think before I act. I now have a pause button---something I did not have in active addiction. I can stop and decide what is best for me. If I don’t know, I know enough to ask someone else. Freedom.
CATS: SOBRIETY / behavior & action,CONFIDENCE / action & behavior,TRIGGERS / awareness,INNER MASTERY / take a step back
WELLGOS: Compulsion KO’r,Self Control 101'r,Self awareness / habits & behavior,WAIT AND SWITCH / Progress
