I look hard at my defects and see what I can do with God’s help to act differently, in a healthier way. Some of my under the hood work was done with a therapist. Some were solo and some were with my husband. I’ve also had to work with therapists to help my teenage daughter deal with anxiety issues. Denial is not an option for me, my history is what it is. If I am not brutally honest with myself and others I risk relapse, or worse...
CATS: TRUTH / Inventory,VULNERABILITY / Show true self,CONFESSION / denial
WELLGOS: Deep Down Diver,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Inventory,VULNERABILITY / admit,RAW SOUL REVEALER / costs,Bitter Truth Taster

RAW: Riding out the urge to pick up can be a challenge. The best way to handle it is to reach out and talk about my feelings about wanting food or discussing an emotional trigger that could make me pick up. One of the things that happens is if I have a problem that is so bad I don’t think I can share it with anyone; then I know that I am in trouble. I worked with a sponsor once and shared with her that I had things in my past that were so painful that I was afraid to write them on paper for anyone to see. She worked with me so I could share those private and painful parts of my history verbally. The things I feel can’t be shared are the very things that must be shared – the dirty secrets of our past. Dirty secrets like physical abuse, sexual abuse, or self abuse are things that will keep us trapped in the addictive cycle and keep us sick. I am only as sick as my secrets. I am fortunate to have several close friends in recovery who know the worst things in my past and I know that no matter what I’ve done or has been done to me, they will always support me. That is a gift of recovery.
CATS: WORTHINESS / help,VULNERABILITY / Show true self,TRUTH / dark past,COMMUNITY / connection with others
WELLGOS: RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,Gratitude Grower,ADMIT / True self & vulnerability,VULNERABILITY / connections

RAW: Some time ago, I went online and found a program that was similar to the one I worked at home and tried to work that program. I learned through this experience, that for me, accountability is really important for my recovery. By going to a face to face meeting at least once a week helps me to check in with myself and with others who can help me to get better. For me, the online options are a helpful supplement to a local meeting, but they don’t replace the necessity for me to be accountable. I have also gained a lot of support from pre-recorded meetings. I will often walk my dog at night and listen to a meeting. I want people to ask where I am, to call me when I am not there. I like being a regular and being missed. I have pretty much concluded that OA is the only game in town for me.
CATS: COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,PROGRESS / support ,SOBRIETY / behavior & action,VULNERABILITY / to support my sobriety
WELLGOS: RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,VULNERABILITY / support from others,COMMITMENT knitter / abstinence confidence

RAW: I love it when I hear people say that they worked the steps and they have 182 amends to make before they can finish their step work. I don’t even know that many people. My understanding of the steps is that I do a fourth step and recall issues that are bothering me. It’s not necessary to write a dissertation and focus on my Sunday school teacher from the first grade, unless there is a serious issue that is bothering me about that. Once I share my 4th step, I can begin the work of making amends and clearing up my past mistakes. After I’ve made amends for past mistakes, I try to make amends as situations arise. Sometimes, I talk to a sponsor about something that happened and get guidance on what my part was and whether an amends is needed. This is an invaluable tool in my recovery and helps me to live an unencumbered life. I am no longer weighed down by past mistakes.
CATS: AMENDS,COMMUNITY / listen to guidance,VULNERABILITY / learning and mistakes
WELLGOS: The First Amender,Amender Befriender,Wrong Righter,VULNERABILITY / support from others,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / admit & amends

RAW: People that share my disease are positive reinforcers for the behaviors that will help me to stay in recovery. They have good attitudes and they walk the walk and don’t just talk the talk. Seeing others who have been transformed from being unhealthy and unhappy to revitalized and peaceful is a gift of my recovery. It is amazing to see the changes in people that sit across from me in the rooms. Instead of looking down, they are looking up with a sparkle in their eye. This gives me hope.
CATS: INFLUENCES,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future,COMMUNITY / connection with others
WELLGOS: Rainbow Hunter,Hope Harvester,NEW LIFE / POSSIBILITIES,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,Joy Sweetener

RAW: Some of the things that can save me from succumbing to my disease are: making a phone call to another recovering person, or working a problem through the steps with another member, or talking about a food situation and developing a plan, or going for a walk with a friend. If I continue to take positive steps in the right direction, I will get better, one healthy behavior at a time one day at a time. It will not happen overnight, but it will happen.
CATS: BABY STEPS / focus on today,COMMUNITY / ask for assistance,VULNERABILITY / others who’ve been there
WELLGOS: Behavior Savior,Progress Pollinator,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / share & learn

RAW: When bad things happen to good people, I get the “pull the covers over my head” feeling and risk going back to the food. I recently lost a friend to alcoholism and it was really hard. Although it did make me question God, I truly believe that there was a positive message for me in her passing. Friends since the 5th grade, as we got older, we started abusing food, alcohol and marijuana together. Twenty years ago, I stopped (through the grace of God) and she kept going. Her disease progressed to a point where her life was a shambles. I said to myself, that could have been me. I felt like I heard God whisper – You’ve been using food like she used alcohol. Food can also kill you, too, it’s just more socially acceptable. Since attending her funeral, I have been really focused on my program and using my message from God in a positive way. I could have used her death as an excuse to keep going and dive into a long-term relapse, but that was not what God had in mind. He is using me to tell her story, she did not die in vain.
CATS: CHANGE / motivations,SOBRIETY / costs & benefits,MINDSET / Future sobriety,VULNERABILITY / learning and mistakes
WELLGOS: Grief Greeter,Grave Trigger,Killer Kickstarter,Black Hole Blesser,Melancholy Melter,Motivation Moonbeamer

RAW: When my program seems too hard, it is important for me to focus on gratitude. Is my life getting better each day? Do I have healthy relationships with people I love? Do I have a healthy relationship to food today? Am I recovering and helping others to do the same? Focusing on the positive aspects and the benefits of recovery helps me to not see the glass as half empty. Are there things that aren’t quite working the way I want them to? Absolutely, but if I focus on the blessings, my blessings multiply. If I focus on the negative things in my life that are bothering me, my life will be more negative.
CATS: GRATITUDE / progress & growth,FREEDOM / peace & harmony,PROGRESS / future & hope,GROWTH / gratitude
WELLGOS: Daily Daisy Spotter,Blessings Detector,Gratitude Flooder

RAW: Who likes to be blamed for things? One of the things that I have learned through recovery is how to accept blame and criticism. It is one of the hardest things to do, to truly listen to someone else’s criticism and really HEAR it. Before recovery, blame would bounce off me, I would not accept it, take it in or do anything to change my behaviors. By putting down the food, opening the channel to God, I can listen to criticisms and ask God to help me to change my negative behavior.
CATS: ACCOUNTABILITY / Own up,BLAME,CONFESSION / admit,VULNERABILITY / learning and mistakes
WELLGOS: The Deblamer,Insight Inseminator,ADMIT / accountability,VULNERABILITY / listen to others

RAW: My favorite thing to do when I am being blamed or criticized is to show how it’s really someone else’s fault. Well, I did this because he did that. I am always playing the martyr role. It’s kind of hard to accept blame when I consider myself to be a martyr and free from blame. I learned in my program that I am flawed in many ways, if I can accept the bad parts of me and try to make them better, I have a fighting chance.
CATS: ACCOUNTABILITY / Own up,BLAME,MINDSET / imperfection & acceptance,CONFESSION / damage & hurt
WELLGOS: Fault Vaulter,The Flawbreaker,ADMIT / accountability,Blame Changer

RAW: Meetings are places that lift my spirits. They open my mind to other people’s point of view. I do not have all the answers. By listening to others, I can learn and be lifted into the light of the spirit. When I am open to other ideas, God can work in my life and he does. When I am fighting the food and struggle in relapse, my mind is closed to God and new ideas. There is only room for my obsession with food. When I put down the food I am open to a better life through divine inspiration.
CATS: COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,FAITH,GOD / thy will
WELLGOS: VULNERABILITY / listen to others,Divine Designer,Cosmic Ray Receiver,Almighty Alchemizer,Thy Will Be Doner

RAW: A phone call to a close friend or a recovering person is sometimes what keeps me on track. One of the steps in my program suggests I work a problem through the steps, own my part and share it with someone else. Afterwards, rather than making another phone call to discuss how I was wronged or to gossip about what happened, I turn my attention to someone I can help. When I call that person, I focus on how I can help them, and not on my own problem. It is an amazing way to handle problems and gives me a whole new way of dealing with life’s challenges.
CATS: GIVING / GENEROSITY,VULNERABILITY / Connection,COMMUNITY / connection with others
WELLGOS: The Empathologist,Metta Motivator,Compassion Weaver,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community

RAW: I spend a lot of my time trying to make things better for people. I am always trying to make everyone happy. Doing this does not allow my loved ones to learn how to handle their own problems. By building bridges to help my family members get along, I am not allowing them to use the gifts God gave them to resolve their own conflicts. I went to an Alanon meeting recently about control and it talked about how I subconsciously do so much to manipulate and control the people that I love without even realizing it. It was a lightbulb moment for me and I’m doing this in several of my relationships.
CATS: CONTROL,INNER / SELF / beliefs & insight,COMMUNITY / healthy relationships
WELLGOS: Relationship Redeemer,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive,Control Unfreaker,Kindness Kickstarter

RAW: In my disease, I burned bridges. They say that hurt people hurt people. I didn’t care about the people that I hurt or what kind of emotional damage I caused them. They say that people in addiction have fair weather friends, they burn a lot of bridges and people don’t hang around them for very long. Yes, they know people at the bar, like Norm at Cheers. But, if they died tomorrow, would the fair weather friends attend their funeral, mourn the loss, support their family? Fair weather friends are there for a good time and not much more. They are usually addicts themselves and don’t really know what a healthy relationship is. I am grateful today for the relationships I have with my family, my friends, my coworkers, and my recovery family. Without my program, I would be living a life of isolation. I no longer have fair weather friends, I have deep, meaningful friendships.
CATS: INFLUENCES,WORTHINESS / connections & sharing,COMMUNITY / healthy relationships
WELLGOS: Foul Weather Friender,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive,Bad Influence Bulldozer

RAW: I believe that change is possible. It is important for me to have faith that God will change me for the better. If I continue to do the next right thing, he will change me. If I sit on my couch bingeing and watching TV, there won’t be many changes happening. When I do the work, keep my food clean, go to meetings, get physical exercise, and stay in constant contact with God – change is not only possible, it’s probable. If I stay in relapse, change feels impossible and life feels hopeless. In recovery, changes happen every day and life feels hopeful.
CATS: WORTHINESS / new life & future,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future,CHANGE / self love & true self,GOD / thy will
WELLGOS: Infinity Infuser,Higher Power Invoker,Almighty Alchemizer,God Grounder,Ever Evolving Flower,Cosmic Ray Receiver

RAW: Do I encourage change? I do my best to focus my energies on making changes in my life with God’s help. Can I make changes all by myself? If I could, I would have done that a long time ago, and wouldn’t be in a recovery program. Practicing recovery behaviors makes the changes in my life possible. Staying focused through program literature and daily meditation readings keeps my focus positive.
CATS: GROWTH / motivation & boosts,GOD / reach out,CHANGE / motivations,VULNERABILITY / to support my sobriety
WELLGOS: God Grounder,Almighty Alchemizer,Thy Will Be Doner

RAW: If you expect the worst, you will get the worst. They say shit happens. If you focus on the positive in life, it will multiply tenfold. I would much rather focus on my recovery than the pain I was in before my recovery or the pain I suffered in relapse. Life is too short to spend it looking backward focused on the pain of my past.
CATS: FREEDOM / past & let go,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future,MINDSET / Future sobriety
WELLGOS: Excrement Expector,NEW LIFE / POSSIBILITIES,Blessings Detector,Journey Jazzer,Rainbow Hunter

RAW: When I came into the rooms, I was out of excuses and reasons why I wasn’t capable of working the program. One of the things that I did early on was give beginners meetings to newcomers. This was helpful because I would tell them about the program and would often hear, well I can’t follow a food plan because I work a crazy schedule. Or, if you had my problems, you’d eat too. It was helpful for me to share my recovery, but also to hear their resistance to recovery. Their resistance was a mirror for me of some of my own inner struggles which helped me to get better.
CATS: CONFESSION / admit,ACCOUNTABILITY / Own up,COMMUNITY / sharing,VULNERABILITY / to support my sobriety
WELLGOS: VULNERABILITY / listen to others,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Share & support,ADMIT / healing

RAW: If I look closely at the reasons I give for not doing certain things, it is funny to see how futile the reasons often are. It is only when people call me on my stuff that the excuses come into play. I am grateful that I have people in my life who care about me enough to be brutally honest with me. In turn, I feel safe to be honest with them and tear down my walls of excuses and do the work. It is only in giving up the excuses that the work can begin.
CATS: TRUTH / Admit addiction,EXCUSES,VULNERABILITY / Show true self
WELLGOS: Excuse Nuker,VULNERABILITY / listen to others,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Face truths,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / motivations

RAW: Through my honesty in meetings and with others who understand my compulsion I can bring my compulsive overeating and addictive behaviors into the light. No longer will my excuses work. I put aside my resistance to what I know will work to get me better and trust God. Making excuses seems like the easier, softer way. But, by keeping me sick and in relapse, the excuses stop working for me. I accept the fact that I have a food problem and begin my journey of recovery.
CATS: CONFESSION / admit,EXCUSES,TRUTH / dark past,COMMUNITY / sharing
WELLGOS: Excuse X’r,ADMIT / healing,VULNERABILITY / admit,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Admit addiction,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / admit & amends

RAW: The entire foundation of 12 step programs is based on the pay-it-forward mentality. If I keep my recovery to myself, pretty soon, I won’t have anything to keep. I work the steps, abstain from my trigger foods and then I put my hand out to the newcomers in the rooms who don’t know where to start. I can also reach out to old timers who have left the rooms and I haven’t seen in a while to see if they are in trouble. It is in giving that I receive. The gifts that I have been given as a result of sharing my program with sponsees are true gems. People you work with think that you are helping them when, in reality, they are helping you.
CATS: GIVING / GENEROSITY,PROGRESS / rewards & proud,COMMUNITY / sharing
WELLGOS: VULNERABILITY / reach out for help,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,Wellectricity Generator,VULNERABILITY / give and receive,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / share & learn

RAW: I try not to focus too much on tomorrow, I focus on one day at a time. I can set positive goals to visualize what I want my future to look like. God can help me to achieve those goals. If I think that reaching those goals is solely up to me, I will fail. If I trust God and ask for his help at each milestone, my goals for the future can be reached. In recovery, I was married, had two beautiful children, graduated from college with honors, bought a beautiful home, and I have a career that I love. I would say the promises are coming true in my life and attaining my life’s goals is possible in recovery. Had I not been in recovery, I doubt most of those things would have happened.
CATS: PROGRESS / start small,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future,BABY STEPS / slow changes
WELLGOS: Blessings Bather,Gratitude Grower,Inner Wealth Welcomer,WAIT AND SWITCH / Small steps,Symbolic Stepper,Baby Step Embracer

RAW: Food gives us instant gratification. Through patience I learn that instant gratification is not always good for us, sometimes waiting for things teaches us important lessons. I want what I want when I want it, which is really only self-will run rampant. Instant gratification is selfish, childish behavior and delayed gratification is a much more mature approach to life.
CATS: MINDSET / will power,SOBRIETY / behavior & action,INNER MASTERY / self control,BABY STEPS / slow changes
WELLGOS: New Pattern Painter / grit & progress,Void Avoider,Illogical Looper,SELF HARM / Self honesty & admit,Frenzy Freezer,COMMITMENT knitter / laziness & effort

RAW: I can accept life’s curve balls when I truly accept that God has a plan for me and what happens is in his hands. If I am challenged, I look for the lessons that God is trying to teach me. What does God want me to get from this hardship? How does he want me to use this experience to change? Like when I lost my friend recently to alcoholism, I asked God, what are you trying to teach me here? There were painful lessons in her death that will impact me for the rest of my life. Do I wish she was still here? Absolutely, the pain is still raw. I can’t eliminate the pain of that loss by turning to my addictive substance. God showed me that loud and clear. That was the lesson in her passing. He chose me to tell her story. But for the grace of God, I could have been the one who died from my addictions at 53.
CATS: GRATITUDE / progress & growth,GROWTH / learning & mistakes,GOD / thy will,CHANGE / courage
WELLGOS: VULNERABILITY / mistakes & learning,Insight Inseminator,Almighty Alchemizer,Thy Will Be Doner,Grave Trigger

RAW: I remember the first meeting I ever went to. It was in a tiny building behind a church. I was in a lot of pain. I drove to the meeting and couldn’t find the building. I drove home distraught because I could not go ONE MORE DAY living in my disease. My mom knew where the meeting was and led me back to the building. In that tiny building, I got my life back. I got the support necessary to deal with my food addiction. It is so important to take the first step and get help. It is in the seeking we find God who gives us the answers we need to live our lives more fully.
CATS: COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,BABY STEPS / Help & support,VULNERABILITY / to support my sobriety
WELLGOS: Scary Stepper,ADMIT / healing,VULNERABILITY / share challenges,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / support groups

RAW: I am not one to handle hostility well. I do not like to rock the boat or make waves, ever. How do I deal with hostile people? I will often shut down, bite my tongue and then talk about how comfortable I am afterwards. I grew up in a household where anger wasn’t displayed very often, so I never learned how to appropriately handle uncomfortable situations like that. In recovery, I feel that my approach is a little healthier, I will try not to feed the person’s anger, but detach and try to let them deal with their own stuff. When I step in, usually it results in the other person blaming their behavior and unhealthy actions on me.
CATS: CONFLICT,ANGER,MINDSET / identify weaknesses
WELLGOS: Vexation Vacationer,Conflict Evictor,Quarrel Quasher,Indignation Ionizer ,Anger X’r

RAW: If I am feeling weak, I will often call my sponsor for support. Sometimes I feel weak due to food issues, emotional issues, or spiritual issues. My disease is three fold – physical, emotional and spiritual. It’s like a three legged stool, if one thing is really off, it can’t stand up. Having someone who has been where I am is helpful to keep me on the straight and narrow. Talking things over with my sponsor keeps me safe from my disease.
CATS: HEALING,COMMUNITY / ask for assistance,VULNERABILITY / others who’ve been there
WELLGOS: VULNERABILITY / reach out for help,RELATIONSHIPS / Meetings & support,Whole Soul Healer

RAW: Before recovery and in relapse I felt like I was always trying to fill a void that could not be filled. No excess food ever made me feel complete. The hole in my sole was a lack of God. By having the addictive substances removed from the life, the channel to God is clear. I don’t always hear his direction. It is important to ask for and listen to direction from God. It is not enough to clear the channel, continual communication with God is required. Praying alone doesn’t work for me. I seek God’s guidance and try to be open to signs for what he wants me to do by listening.
CATS: WORTHINESS / help,CONFESSION / powerlessness,HIGHER POWER / surrender,VULNERABILITY / Show true self
WELLGOS: CLOSET CONFESSOR / Share & support,God Grounder,Higher Power Invoker,Insight Inseminator,VULNERABILITY / share with god

RAW: Making snap decisions is usually motivated by emotion. Recently, I had a problem that I felt an urgency to address. I made an instant decision to blurt it out on the phone when I was in a weak state with one of the partners in my agency. After that, I had another instance where I was triggered by something that happened that made me fearful, and I pushed for a follow up conversation. I finally had the conversation and it didn’t go as I had hoped. Later, I prayed about the situation and asked God to help me with my fears and a completely different solution presented itself. From the first day I pursued this alternative solution to my problem I have been excited and centered in my approach and I know that this is the direction God wanted me to go in all along. If I am unsure how to handle something, I will pause and ask God what how he wants me to proceed.
CATS: WORTHINESS / help,GOD / reach out,VULNERABILITY / learning and mistakes
WELLGOS: Problem Primer,Soul-vation ,Frenzy Freezer,God Grounder,VULNERABILITY / share with god

RAW: Taking an inventory is extremely helpful for me when I am having difficulty. I do a 4th step in my program which asks me who/what I am resentful, angry, or fearful about and why. Identify which of the following are affected by the situation: self esteem, pride, emotional security, financial security, personal relations or sexual relations. Am I being: selfish, dishonest, self-seeking or inconsiderate? What is my part, how am I contributing to the problem or what is the exact nature of my part in the problem? Next, I pray on the issue and then call another recovering compulsive overeater to discuss. I don’t dwell on the wrong or fear I am having, I focus on my part and then let the problem go. After I hang up, I turn my attention to another member that I can help without mentioning my problem to the other person. Doing this has saved me on a number of occasions.
CATS: TRUTH / Inventory,FREEDOM / tools & strategies,CONFESSION / damage & hurt
WELLGOS: CLOSET CONFESSOR / Inventory,I-Examiner,I-Opener,Self awareness / confidence to admit,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Face truths

RAW: I cannot judge others in my program if they are having difficulty. It is important to reach out to others in the rooms who are struggling. In my family, if I stand in judgment of others, I am assuming that I am above reproach. I will focus today on the people who I interact with and withhold my judgment of them and their actions. I cannot take the position of a martyr who thinks that they are better than others. We are all children of God.
CATS: WORTHINESS / connections & sharing,JUDGMENTS,COMMUNITY / connection with others
WELLGOS: Judgment Jailer,Metta Motivator,Kindness Kickstarter,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community

RAW: Labeling people is a form of judgment. Focusing on labeling them based on the way that they behave is not fair treatment. Once again, my recovery is a full time job. I do not have time in my life to focus on the people around me and what they are or are not doing. If I am spending time worrying about someone else’s actions it often means that there is something about the other person that is showing me something within myself that needs my attention. If I can identify what that is, I can focus on changing myself and not the other person.
CATS: LABELS / STIGMA,GROWTH / willing to change,INNER / SELF / awareness
WELLGOS: Label Eraser,Judgment Junker,Inner I-Opener,Soul Tuner,VULNERABILITY / Radical self honesty

RAW: People in the rooms who are relapsing with food or experiencing emotional relapse or discomfort deserve compassion. It is important to remember that I am flawed and that God does not make perfect people. Slips are often part of someone’s recovery. Who am I to judge someone else’s recovery? Some people are able to come into the rooms and get clean and stay clean. Others can never quite get the recovery they are seeking. Still others, get clean and then have trouble with relapse. Who is to say that the one who gets it and keeps it is any better than the others who are working on their recovery? It is important to stay connected to whatever program you are working. If you leave the recovery rooms, especially if you are struggling, you may never get better.
CATS: COMPASSION,JUDGMENTS,COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups
WELLGOS: Compassion Moonlighter,The Empathologist,Metta Motivator,RELATIONSHIPS / Meetings & support

RAW: I am always looking for ways to fall under the radar. Being a middle child, that is always where I am comfortable. Not the best, but certainly not the worst. In recovery, I seek the optimum solution, I cannot be lazy and seek middle of the road recovery. I work towards doing my best to work a program each day. By doing so, I can be assured a better life for myself and my loved ones. If I look for the middle of the road solution, it may not get me the recovery that I is required. I get in – what I put out.
CATS: MINDSET / obstacles & challenge,MOTIVATION,CONFESSION / admit
WELLGOS: The Procrastina-shunner,Lazy Zapper,Distract-shunner,Gripe Sniper,COMMITMENT knitter / abstinence confidence

RAW: Am I being a distraction in my recovery program? Do I focus on amusing people and not taking my disease seriously? I am doomed to relapse if I consider my program and my recovery simply an amusing diversion. Being fully engaged in recovery is a necessity for me. My recovery meetings are not for my amusement, they are to be taken seriously.
CATS: COMMITMENTS,SOBRIETY / maintaining & will power,MINDSET / Perceptions
WELLGOS: Monkey Mind Cleanser,Distraction Assassin,The Blocksmither,Illogical Looper,Inner Trash Trasher

RAW: Sometimes, I feel like my disease is a monster on my shoulder. It is telling me, go ahead – you can have a cheat day. Dieters have an occasional sweet item, why can’t you? You don’t really have a disease, you can eat like other people. The minute I pick up, the monster on my shoulder tells me otherwise. I feel hopeless and depressed and like I have no defense against the next bite. If I don’t pick up the first bite, I won’t have to struggle with the urge to have the second or third bite. The first bite triggers the phenomenom of craving.
CATS: SABOTAGE,DEMONS,RELAPSE,WARNINGS / Avoid triggers
WELLGOS: Gremlin Greeter,Sabotage SOS’r,SELF HARM / Warnings,Demon Dethroner ,The Debinger,Just One Justifier

RAW: A lot of my recovery behaviors are mood elevators. Things that I do that make me feel connected to God help to elevate my moods. I love to garden, there is something about having my hands in the dirt that helps me to connect with my higher power. When I am at the beach or anywhere near water, I feel peaceful and closer to God. Exercising through walking or yoga are also mood elevators for me. The more I incorporate these behaviors, they less often I turn to food to feel better.
CATS: MOODS,GROWTH / behavior & habits,JOY,INNER / SELF / patterns
WELLGOS: Feelings Felicitizer,Joy Kickstarter,Good Will Gardener,New Pattern Painter

RAW: Monitoring my moods is important for me. It is important that I focus on not being too Hungry Angry Lonely or Tired (HALT). I can make sure I don’t allow too much time between meals to deal with my hunger. For my anger, I can work the steps to process my feelings so I don’t eat over them. If I am feeling lonely, I can reach out to recovery friends or other friends and make plans to get together. If I am tired, I can get the rest necessary to feel better.
CATS: MOODS,FREEDOM / tools & strategies,MINDSET / Future sobriety,GROWTH / supporting myself
WELLGOS: Feelings Flipper,SELF HARM / Tools,I-examiner - reactions & behavior

RAW: When I am trying to control someone else’s behavior it is important that I check my motivations. I am doing too much to help one of my kids because I don’t want them to fail at something? If I never let them fail, they will not learn to deal with the negative consequences of their behavior. Often I am trying to control others due to my own selfish reasons. It’s not really about the other person, it is all about me. Getting in touch with my motivations can help me to make better decisions about the things that I am doing for the wrong reasons.
CATS: INNER POWER / Decisions,CONTROL,MOTIVATION,INNER MASTERY / beliefs & awareness
WELLGOS: The Control-aholic,I-examiner - motivations,ADMIT / Decisions & beliefs

RAW: Working on having a positive attitude is what I focus on in my recovery. My recovery behaviors are a direct challenge to my negative beliefs. My tendency, unchecked is to lean toward the victim role – the negative in a given situation. By working a recovery program, I am more grounded, centered and God-focused. When I am in a grounded, God-focused state I don’t normally experience negative feelings. I believe that God wants me to be recovered. It is evidenced by how much better my life is in recovery.
CATS: NEGATIVITY,PROGRESS / future & hope,GOD / thy will,CHANGE / mental confidence
WELLGOS: Negativity Ninja,God Grounder,Victim Vaccinator,THOUGHTS / positivity

RAW: When I first came to the program, I was fully immersed in the program because it allowed me an opportunity to change the path my life was headed. I have been grateful that although I have not always stayed on the straight and narrow and have not always done things perfectly, I can truly say, the new life that I was given as a result of my recovery is so much better than where my life was headed before recovery. If I continue on my imperfect path of recovery, only God knows the gifts that I will continue to receive. I am certain that I will receive more Gifts in my life from recovery, because God has blessed me so much in the past decade as I have worked on my recovery.
CATS: PROGRESS / future & hope,GRATITUDE / progress & growth,GROWTH / celebrate
WELLGOS: Blessings Bather,Gratitude Flooder,NEW LIFE / POSSIBILITIES,Rainbow Hunter

RAW: Do the next right thing. One of the things my mom always says is if there is a problem that you can’t resolve, do the next right thing. Don’t focus on the problem, I do what I would have done if I didn’t have the program. It’s the idea that if I am doing the next thing that I am supposed to do, God will help to solve my problem. It is when I force solutions that things don’t work out in my favor. Sometimes, it’s because I am forcing my will and not God’s will on others. If something is forced and I feel resistance it is often because I am not following God’s will. This idea can even help when trying to find something I have lost.
CATS: INNER MASTERY / challenge & resilience,CONFIDENCE /  obstacles & challenge,PROGRESS / reactions & behavior
WELLGOS: Soul-ution Finder,Thy Will Be Doner,Problem Soul-ver

RAW: Talking to newcomers in the room reinforces for me why I am in recovery. Working with sponsees is also a reinforcer. I don’t need to sit alone in a room and work the steps every day to stay recovered. But, I do need to work the steps. I do this by working them with a sponsor when I come into the rooms. Each time I work with a sponsee and take them through the 12 steps, I am reinforcing what I need to hear and do.
CATS: COMPASSION,COMMUNITY / Meetings & groups,VULNERABILITY / others who’ve been there
WELLGOS: VULNERABILITY / support from others,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,Metta Motivator,The Empathologist,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / share & learn

RAW: As a recovering person, I do an inventory to clear away the wreckage of my past. One of the things that I have learned through this process is: it is important for me to accept responsibility for my past and present behaviors. By focusing on my part and what defects of character come into play when I am angry and resentful, I can work to change my behavior going forward. If I walk around angry or resentful at everyone I come into contact with, I cannot stay recovered, I will eventually relapse. By working the steps and accepting responsibility, I have a fighting chance to get better.
CATS: ACCOUNTABILITY / Own up,RESPONSIBILITY,TRUTH / Inventory
WELLGOS: Responsibility Rebooter,ADMIT / accountability,Anger Gangster,The Indigna-Shunner ,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Inventory

RAW: There are a few people in my life, the ones I could call at any time, day or night that I would call my safety net. Some are in recovery, some I have known since childhood and some I have known since my kids were young. Before recovery I had friends, but not the type of friends I have today. These friends are people who know me and care what happens to me. Before, a lot of my relationships were superficial. The relationships with the people I care about are important to my growth today and I value them. It is important for me to maintain my relationships so that I can call on my friends to support me and vice versa.
CATS: WORTHINESS / help,COMMUNITY / healthy relationships,VULNERABILITY / Connection
WELLGOS: Foul Weather Friender,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / share & learn

RAW: The steps can really be used to change my life. My life today is beyond my wildest dreams and when I think of where it could have ended up, I shudder. I am still amazed that God chose me to get better. Using the steps in my life, I am able to make changes in my life that I never thought possible. I didn’t have a healthy relationship until I became recovered. I would never have been a good mom unless I became recovered. Being a mother was one of the most beautiful gifts of my recovery. I am not perfect, but Iknowthatonedayatatime,IhavethetoolstobethebestmomthatIcanbe. WhenI fall short, I ask God to help me make the necessary amends to the people that I love.
CATS: FREEDOM / peace & harmony,GRATITUDE / for self,CHANGE / self love & true self,GROWTH / celebrate
WELLGOS: Endorphin Flooder,Gratitude Flooder,Joy Flooder,Favorade,Divine Designer,Bliss Kisser

RAW: I would never tell a friend the nasty things that I would tell myself, before recovery. I was constantly beating myself up for not being perfect or good enough. Today, if I am having a bad day, I step back and look at what is going on and try not to abuse myself for not doing everything right. Today, I had a lot of technical challenges, and I made a few mistakes. I was not in the best mood because of this. Does this mean I am a terrible worker and that I can’t do anything right? They say that when an addict gets a flat tire, they call suicide prevention. This for me, sums up the self-talk. Now, when I get a flat tire, I actually call AAA, not suicide prevention.
CATS: CONFIDENCE / acceptance & worth,WORTHINESS / self love & acceptance,INNER / SELF / patterns
WELLGOS: Self Awareness Awakener,THOUGHTS / aware & examine,Kindness Kickstarter,Metta Motivator,Self Esteem Elixir,Inner I-Opener

RAW: I used to tolerate intolerable situations. Mostly, because I had low self-esteem. I didn’t feel worthy. Today, I can detach from situations that bother me and go do something healthy for myself. If someone is egging me on in an argument, I do not engage if it could be harmful to me. I have choices about how I respond to situations today. In my disease, I would fly off the handle and not deal with situations appropriately. In recovery, I no longer have to tolerate unacceptable behavior. Two wrongs don’t make a right.
CATS: SITUATIONS,CONFIDENCE /  obstacles & challenge,RESILIENCE / reaction & behavior
WELLGOS: Situation Detacher,Self Worth Surfer,Inner Guru Guarder,Conflict Connoisseur,SELF HARM / Tools

RAW: The things that I value have come into clearer focus as I am recovering. In my disease, I valued unhealthy relationships, unhealthy behaviors and an unhealthy lifestyle. In my recovery I value healthy relationships, I value recovery behaviors and I am truly grateful for the life I have today. Instead of fair weather friends who didn’t truly value me as a friend, I have people who truly care about me and support me in my recovery.
CATS: VALUES,GRATITUDE / progress & growth,WORTHINESS / connections & sharing,COMMUNITY / healthy relationships
WELLGOS: RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,Foul Weather Friender,Values VIP’r

RAW: Recovery is quite a ride. It has it’s ups and downs. It’s like riding a crazy wave. Some days I am truly grateful to be recovered and some days are challenging. My worst days in recovery do not even compare to my worst days in my disease. I would not even trade my challenging days in recovery for anything because they have taught me how to work through life’s ups and downs in a healthier way.
CATS: GRATITUDE / progress & growth,GROWTH / learning & mistakes,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future
WELLGOS: Bipolar Coaster,Wellectricity Generator,Spiritual Conquest-ador,WAIT AND SWITCH / Progress,Hurtle Hugger

RAW: I can’t make all the wrongs in my life right. I can’t fix all the things I ever did wrong. I can make amends to the people who I have harmed and start fresh. I make daily amends by behaving differently and not con=nuing the same nega=ve behaviors. If I am having difficulty ac=ng differently, I can rely on God to help me to change. Eventually, the wrongs I have done will not be in vain I learn to live differently.
CATS: ACCOUNTABILITY / Amends,CONFESSION / apology & forgiveness,RESPONSIBILITY,FREEDOM / past & let go
WELLGOS: Wrong Righter,Amender Amen’r,Relationship Dedamager,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Face truths,ADMIT / accountability,Responsibility 101’r

RAW: One of the ways that I manage my nerves and my fear is to reach out to God. Often, when I am nervous in a situation like before a test or something important, I don’t always have the luxury of speaking to another person about my feelings and God helps me the most to calm my nerves and ease my fears. Writing about my nerves as well as my fears helps to right-size them and gives me the ability to see how I can change so that I am not so fearful and nervous.
CATS: GOD / reach out,ANXIETY,INNER POWER / Fears & Strength
WELLGOS: Nerve Ninja,God Grounder,Fear Firewaller,VULNERABILITY / share with god

RAW: When I have done something wrong, one of the hardest things that I do is to make amends. It is not only sharing what I did with someone else, but sharing directly to the individual what I did to harm them. I don’t like to own up to my wrong-doings, it brings me pain. But, keeping them locked in my heart will only make my pain greater. Releasing the pain by making amends will truly help me to walk with God and be as he would have me be. If I have wronged someone, I need to determine if I will harm them more by making amends. Even if it will make me feel better, if it will harm someone else, I really must examine my motives for making an apology.
CATS: ACCOUNTABILITY / Own up,CONFESSION / apology & forgiveness,AMENDS,RECONCILIATON
WELLGOS: My Badiator,ADMIT / accountability,The First Amender,Forgiveness Rusher,Relationship Redeemer,Wrong Righter

RAW: Do I like apologies? No, I don’t. I was fortunate to be able to write amends letters to my children and share them with them. I think it was a little embarrassing for them, me sharing so honestly with them. One of the things that I am grateful for is that it teaches them that parents can be honest and humble and truthful. It was a God-directed recovery experience that I am grateful for. Apologies can be uncomfortable, painful and awkward, somehow writing amends letters and reading them makes them easier to do. Amends are an important part of my recovery program. I cannot continue as a recovering addict if I carry around the baggage of my past mistakes.
CATS: CONFESSION / apology & forgiveness,ACCOUNTABILITY / Amends,RECONCILIATON
WELLGOS: Apology Amen’r,ADMIT / honesty,VULNERABILITY / admit,Amender Amen’r

RAW: When I feel that I am right, I can really push in an argument. This is not a place God wants me to live. Even though I may feel that I am right, I don’t always have to prove it and pound the point home. Focusing on getting my feelings across in an argument isn’t respectful of the other person that I am arguing with. Holding onto anger and resentment is a killer for me. When I am most angry, I am better off walking away and processing and looking for MY PART in the disagreement. Often, in the heat of the moment, all I can see is the other person’s part. Focusing on MY PART, helps me to be more understanding of the other person’s short comings. We are not all perfect, God made us all and I choose to treat people as I would want to be treated.
CATS: ACCOUNTABILITY / Own up,CONFLICT,PRIDE
WELLGOS: Quarrel Quasher,Pride Polisher,ADMIT / accountability,Anger Vacationer

RAW: When I feel angry, all my defects come out to play. I’ll show them, I’ll suck the whole word into my angry place by gossiping about the other person. Gossiping about my anger only fuels the flames for me to continue to carry a resentment. I had a situation recently and I will think of a very simple response to anyone that asks me about what happened in this situation. That way, I will not hurt myself or the other person by continuing to fan the flames of my anger and retelling the story with each and every gory detail. If it continues to come up, I will continue to pray about it and talk to my sponsor and then focus on helping someone else. Anger is not an emotion that I am at luxury to exercise whenever I feel like it. My anger hurts me more than it hurts others. Attending meetings and talking to recovery friends helps me to process my anger in a more healthy way.
CATS: ANGER,INNER MASTERY / tools & processes,RESILIENCE / discomfort,RECONCILIATON
WELLGOS: Anger Gangster,The Defuriator,Venom Vaporizer

RAW: One of the ways that I process anger and resentment is by praying for the people that have harmed me. My father used to say, “Pray for the bastards.” What that means is, yes, we feel harmed by them. Yes, when we begin this prayer, we are still angry and consider them bastards. But, as we pray for them every single day, we pray for the things we want for ourselves for them, our anger dissipates. Amazingly, after a time, God will heal our hearts and we may repair relationships with people we feel have harmed us. Sometimes, we are not healed enough to continue interaction, that is ok as long as we are not keeping our anger locked in our hearts. If continuing a relationship will jeopardize my recovery, I have to make the decision to either put the relationship on hold or end it altogether. My recovery is too precious to play with.
CATS: GOD / thy will,ANGER,RECONCILIATON,HEALING
WELLGOS: The Defuriator,Relationship Redeemer,Higher Power Invoker,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive

RAW: Anger will only harden my heart. I cannot live in a place of anger and resentment. In the heat of the moment, sometimes I feel like the only way is to stay angry. Staying angry at another person and harboring resentment will only harm me, not them. God does not want me to live in a place of anger. By trusting God and asking him to show me my part, I can learn to release my anger to the universe and move forward in a positive way. If I don’t deal with anger, it will fester and harden my heart and soul and keep me stuck. When I process my anger in a more positive way, God will give me hope for the future and help me to live a more positive life one day at a time.
CATS: ANGER,HIGHER POWER / surrender,FREEDOM / past & let go,HOPE
WELLGOS: Angerexia,Self Harm Alarmer,Almighty Alchemizer,Peace Pollinator,Soul Synchronizer

RAW: In the depths of my disease and pain in my life, I have felt little hope. Before I returned to my recovery program several years ago, I felt like I was in a deep hole of agony that there was no way out of. It’s almost like while I was in that place, there was a sewer grate on top of the black hole I was in, with only two tiny slats of light shining in. As I reached out and went back to my program, the two tiny slats of light got bigger. Now, the sewer grate is off completely and light shines into my life each and every day. Some days, I still experience pain that makes me feel like the sewer grate was put back on top of the hole. These are times that God wants me to go to him to find out what I can do to change so that the grate will be lifted again and he can shine his love down upon me again.
CATS: AGONY,GOD / thy will,FREEDOM / future & growth,INNER / SELF / beliefs & insight,FAITH
WELLGOS: Black Hole Blesser,Cosmic Ray Receiver,Inner Light Illuminator,Grace Moonlighter,Melancholy Melter,Faith Flooder

RAW: Sometimes, people focus on blaming others for all of their problems, but have the inability to accept any blame themselves. Looking to our part in the challenges we face is a good way to learn and grow in our recovery. As an addict, I spent a lot of time feeling sorry for myself and blaming others for the condition of my life. It kind of hardens your heart to the people around you when you are always pointing the finger at everyone else. In recovery, when I have a problem, I look for my part in the situation and work to make changes so that I don’t continue the same patterns of behavior. It’s said, “If I continue to do what I always do, I will continue to get what I always got.” Shining the light on our own transgressions is a gift that God gives me so that I can grow and change one day at a time.
CATS: GROWTH / learning & mistakes,ACCOUNTABILITY / De-blame,RESPONSIBILITY,CONFESSION / damage & hurt
WELLGOS: Blamenesia,ADMIT / accountability,Relationship Redeemer,Responsibility 101’r,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Inventory,VULNERABILITY / mistakes & learning

RAW: Who is truly to blame for the wrongs that happen to me? Are they really everyone else’s fault, or is there something I am bringing into my relationships that is unhealthy that causes me to blame everyone else for what happens to me? Recovery helped me to stop feeling sorry for myself and living under a dark cloud. With God’s help, I can turn the focus from outward to inward and bring about changes in my life. It is said, “When I have a finger pointed at someone ￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼￼else, there are three more pointing right back at me.” Recovery gives me the willingness to change myself rather than blaming others for everything that I don’t like about my life.
CATS: ACCOUNTABILITY / De-blame,TRUTH / Inventory,CONFESSION / admit
WELLGOS: Blame Changer,Fault Vaulter,ADMIT / accountability,I-Examiner,Self awareness / confidence to admit

RAW: Are there reasons that I can be bitter about my past or my current situation – yes. Is that how God wants me to spend my time – no. Bitterness and anger are a cancer that can spread to all other areas of my life. If I have anger about a work situation, it doesn’t stay at work if I bring it home, talk about it and carry it into my personal like. The same is true if I am in pain in my home relationships, this can often carry into my work life and relationships with friends. When we spend all of our energy being angry and bitter, friends do not want to spend time with us. I have a person that I knew that I used to call Eoyore, like in Winnie the Pooh. No matter what was going on in her life, she always had an “Oh, dear, Oh my, whoa is me” kind of attitude. Not the most pleasant person to be around. By quitting the negativity and bitter attitude, we draw positive people to our lives that help us be more positive. I am what I attract to my life and for today, I choose to quit being bitter.
CATS: BITTERNESS,OPTIMISM,MINDSET / Perceptions,FREEDOM / peace & harmony
WELLGOS: Bitter Quitter,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive,Attitude Alchemizer,Feelings Felicitizer,Gripe Sniper

RAW: Sometimes, things have good and bad aspects to them. Like saying goodbye to a close friend who is moving away. One time, my son’s friends were moving away and he was upset about it. We celebrated their going away, took some pictures with him and his friends and focused on the positive aspects of being their neighbors. I told my son, “Be grateful that you had friends you cared enough about to experience the pain of losing them.” The next day, in our mailbox, my son received a note that said, “Thanks for being my friend”. Thank you God for the beautiful life lessons that you share with me each and every day. When I feel sadness, I embrace the bittersweet aspect of that sadness and appreciate the good that underlies the sad feelings. If I eat over sadness, I won’t experience the good that comes out of the sad events in my life. If I was in relapse or not in recovery, I would not have taken the time to help my son to process his feelings about his friend moving away. My focus would have been on my own needs or focusing on my next binge. As a person in recovery, I can greet the bittersweet moments in life and embrace the life lessons that come with them.
CATS: FREEDOM / peace & harmony,GROWTH / learning & mistakes,INNER / SELF / beliefs & insight,GROWTH / gratitude
WELLGOS: Bittersweet Greeter,VULNERABILITY / mistakes & learning,Joy Kickstarter,The Blessifier,Gratitude Guru,The Mindfulizer

RAW: In my recovery, I have been blessed to meet people that I have known for the past 30 years. People who, even if I have not spoken to recently, if I was in trouble, I could call at any time of the day or night. One was my first sponsor who was there for me when I first became recovered and lost 75 pounds, when I had both my children in recovery, when I lost my dad, when I got married, and when I graduated from college. People in my recovery who know me know me on a much deeper level. They know me and accept me for who I am and are there for me. I have also been blessed with people who truly care about me that are not in recovery. I have close friends who are very supportive of me, accept the fact that I am in recovery and would do anything for me. Friendship is a two way street, you cannot have good friends unless you are a good friend. In recovery, I have learned some hard lessons about friendship that I will carry with me and try to apply to be a better friend to the people I care about.
CATS: GRATITUDE / for others,LOVE ,COMMUNITY / healthy relationships
WELLGOS: Beloved BFF’r,Foul Weather Friender,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community,Metta Motivator,Love Flooder

RAW: Do I focus on controlling others – yes. I spend a lot of time discussing my husbands’ work with him and giving my opinions on how I feel things should be handled. Does he know exactly what I do and how would I feel if he constantly gave me advice on how I should handle things at work. My teenage daughter brings up the same things. I am constantly trying to manage her time, judging what I feel she should or should not be doing. Telling her things like, “you’re spending too much time on your phone, did you clean your room, and have you even started your homework”. Micromanaging her life shows my disapproval and makes her feel like I don’t trust her to make her own decisions. With teenagers, there is a fine line. If I don’t tell her to do anything, she will ask me to push her or call her on what she is doing? When I do it too much, it turns her off. Being a recovered mom is not an easy job, but a very fulfilling one if I am open to changing my behaviors. In the same way that I like to control others, I like to be in control. I feel very threatened when I must rely on someone else and I can’t trust that my needs will be met. For me, I often will do something and resent doing it rather than ask for help. I am learning to ask for help and give up some of the control in my life and allow others to help me.
CATS: CONTROL,INNER / SELF / patterns,COMMUNITY / ask for assistance
WELLGOS: The Control-aholic,VULNERABILITY / reach out for help,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive,Powerholic Healer

RAW: Busyness is sometimes what I use to stuff my feelings down. When I am focused on outside things and not God-centered and doing my daily recovery behaviors, I am putting my recovery at risk. When I am busy, I sometimes don’t follow my food plan the way that I should, by skipping meetings or skipping items on my food plan. This will eventually catch up with me. Shortcuts never work for me. It’s all or nothing. There is a saying in recovery, half measures avail us nothing. I work towards being “all in” to work a healthy program. If I don’t commit to working my program consistently, I am not assured a long term recovery. If I find myself really distracted by things in my life that are taking a priority over my recovery, I need to take the necessary steps to shift my focus to what is truly important because my recovery has to become first. Everything that I put before my recovery I will lose in relapse.
CATS: COMMITMENTS,SOBRIETY / maintaining & will power,INNER MASTERY / self control
WELLGOS: Distraction Assassin,New Pattern Painter,Values VIP’r,COMMITMENT knitter / above all else

RAW: One of the reasons that addicts do what we do is all we care about is ourselves. We are centered on our own desires and needs and don’t really care about who is hurt in the process. One of the ways that I can turn that mindset around is to focus on others. One of the ways that I can work my own program is by sharing my recovery with others. I can do this by sharing at meetings, talking to newcomers or people who are struggling at meetings. I also try to reach out to people who are in relapse and are not in the rooms to let them know that I am available when they are ready to come back. By focusing on others, my ego is right sized and I can reinforce my own recovery.
CATS: EGO,COMPASSION,GIVING / GENEROSITY,COMMUNITY / sharing
WELLGOS: Ego X’r,Arrogance Arrestor,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive,Metta Motivator,The Empathologist,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / share & learn

RAW: I have recently been doing both recovery work and work in my career that has boosted my confidence. Learning new things and doing things that are challenging, is not easy. But, when things start to click, it is a huge confidence booster. It’s like having confidence on steroids or a confidence caffeinator. I feel like I suddenly have more energy and enthusiasm than I did before, I am excited about the things that I am focused on that are helping me to learn and grow. Each new project that I take on can boost my confidence level. Have I done everything perfectly, absolutely not. I have made some huge mistakes, but God is using them as learning opportunities to show me where I can learn and grow. Learning and growing is not easy, but the gratification that comes from stretching myself personally and professionally is immeasurable.

WELLGOS: Confidence Caffeinator,NEW LIFE / POSSIBILITIES,Rainbow Hunter,Journey Jazzer

RAW: Through recovery, I have come to know a spiritual side to my life that I cannot express enough gratitude for. I have found things that bring me sheer bliss. Things that, when I was in my disease, I would never do, like quilting, gardening, writing, yoga, walking, or photography. In addiction, I was focused on eating unhealthy foods that there was no time to explore the things that brought me joy and fulfillment. The things that I have learned about myself in recovery have brought me a sense of inner divinity or serenity that I never dreamed possible. Through recovery, I have learned that I have a number of talents that I never would have explored in my disease. In recovery, there is room in my life and energy for other more positive things that give me a true feeling of inner peace and fulfillment.

RAW: In my disease, I would always look down. I was too tired to focus on the beauty around me. Even though I am older than I was before I got recovery, I feel younger inside. I see the daily blessings all around me. Walking in my yard in the spring and checking to see what is coming up first, like the first daffodil. Or taking my dog into the yard to play with a ball every day at lunch time. These are small gifts of recovery, but they bring me joy and gratitude. I don’t necessarily focus on the flowers every day, but when I do, I have much better days.
CATS: GRATITUDE / opportunities,FREEDOM / peace & harmony,CONFIDENCE /  hope & future,JOY
WELLGOS: Daily Daisy Spotter,Gratitude Grower,Blessings Detector,Joy Flooder,Inner Wealth Welcomer

RAW: You can find me in the garden early in the morning. When I am out there, I am connected to God and the universe and the daily problems just melt away. There is something about getting my hands into the soil that connects me to God and makes me feel relaxed. The day-to-day problems seem to melt away when I am working in my yard. Before recovery, I was never up early, I would be hungover from alcohol or excess food and didn’t do anything that centered me. I felt that I would get centered from eating and drinking, but little did I know, it had the opposite effect. I am so grateful for the moments that I have in my life today where I connect with God and find my bliss.
CATS: GRATITUDE / progress & growth,HIGHER POWER / surrender,FREEDOM / peace & harmony
WELLGOS: Gratitude Gardener,God Grounder,Bliss Kisser,New Pattern Painter

RAW: Key concept — doing a ‘gratitude flood’ is flooding yourself with feelings of gratitude One of the gifts of recovery is the flood of gratitude that I feel when I have God centered moments. They can be in nature when I am at the beach on a beautiful day or at the park when I am working my dog. I can even feel tremendous gratitude when I hear a spiritual song or any song that I connect with. I have been brought to tears in a positive way by songs that hit me during moments where I am flooded with gratitude. Some days, I have to work to find things to be grateful for, but there is always something to be grateful for. Finding gratitude on a bad day is more important that finding gratitude on a good day. It is easy to see all the good around me on the good days. Even on the bad days, I try really hard to flood myself with feelings of gratitude because there are always things that I can be grateful for.

RAW: The love that I feel for my husband and children is something I never thought I would experience. As an addict, I was extremely isolated and never thought I would ever marry let alone have children. The life that I am living today is truly beyond my wildest dreams. To think it all started about 25 years ago when a friend of my father’s said to me, “How are you ever going to find a husband and get married looking like that.” My biggest fears personified. Instead of taking offense, I took this statement as a challenge, I lost 75 pounds in recovery and went to visit him to show him how much better I was doing. I cannot imagine a life without my soulmate and would never have been complete without the two children that I love and adore. When we are all together, I am flooded with the love that I feel for each of them.

RAW: I have found my bliss since I came into the rooms of OA in my recovery. It’s not just about a food plan, it is a totally different way to live. Having such a full life, learning what brings me true joy is something I never would have thought was possible. If you are struggling in relapse or have not been able to get recovered, it is worth the effort. Living a life of recovery can bring you spiritual bliss, emotional bliss, professional bliss and personal bliss. Did I think that having this many areas of my life that bring me joy would ever be possible – no. These are the promises of recovery.

RAW: Peace and serenity are two of the side benefits of recovery. Before recovery, I thrived on chaos and I was constantly in a state of anxiousness. I had no idea that such a better life awaited me through putting down the addictive substances that I thought I had to have. I didn’t think I could relate to people without the substances I abused. Talk about addictive thinking. Putting down addictive substances has opened a channel for peace in my life that I never thought I would experience. Do I feel peaceful every single day? Not necessarily, but a good or bad day in recovery is 10x better than a day in my disease.

RAW: How do I work on my procrastination? I struggle with this defect on a regular basis. Sometimes, I can break a big project that I have been procrastinating about into smaller projects so the project is easier to manage. It’s like baby steps instead of scaling the entire staircase. I can handle the baby steps associated with certain projects. Focusing on the whole task often brings about the procrastination. Another thing that helps is focusing on parts of the project and then revisiting it again the next day. This way, I have a fresh perspective and can give a good effort to what needs to be done. I can also bookend the task. Talk to a recovering friend and tell them what I plan to do to get started, then begin the project and talk to someone when I am done.
CATS: PROGRESS / start small,COMMITMENTS,COMMUNITY / sharing,BABY STEPS / Help & support
WELLGOS: Killer Kickstarter,The Procrastina-shunner,WAIT AND SWITCH / Small steps,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / share & learn

RAW: Recovery opens my heart and makes me a kinder wife and mother. All of my recovery behaviors are the catalyst for kindness. If I am in relapse, I am depressed, moody, miserable and not fun to be around. Maintaining fit, spiritual condition in my program can almost guarantee that I will be more kind to others most of the time. If I am having difficulty and am not feeling kind, I can share with another recovering member or my sponsor and work on my feelings.

WELLGOS: Kindness Kickstarter,VULNERABILITY / support from others,Metta Motivator,Soul Synchronizer

RAW: A few things in my program can kick start my serenity. A long walk, a yoga class, reading program literature, talking to a recovering friend, or reading a meditation reading. When I am feeling stressed writing is also an excellent tool that aids in my recovery and can help me feel more serene and peaceful. Getting my feelings down on paper and releasing them to my higher power makes me feel better. Sometimes, rather than focusing on what I assume the problem is, I focus on other more positive aspects of my recovery which is very helpful. When I am not in a good place, it’s important that I look at my kit of “peace Kickstarter” behaviors that will help me towards feeling more serene.

RAW: I hate the labels addict and alcoholic. Although I had alcoholism in my family, I was so focused on the stigma, I may never have gotten help if I had to go to AA first. Society puts such a negative emphasis on the “ism” and not the recovering addicts. I wish that more people would embrace the recovering people in their lives with love and support instead of expecting them to fail. I would love to erase the labels that people use for addicts along with the negative connotations that go along with them. If that would happen, I think more people would embrace a life of recovery.

Now, that I am on the other side of these labels and see the recovery from these addictions, I have a different perspective. An addict who admits they have a problem, reaches out and gets recovery is a GOOD THING. Often, I hear more about the practicing addicts and not those who are successful members of society because they got help. All addicts deserve respect and kindness no matter where they are in their recovery.

RAW: I often wonder, how I survived a life of addiction. Both my early childhood, with an alcoholic parent and a lot of painful dysfunction in my home. How did God choose to save me and not someone else? When I first found out my father was being treated for alcoholism when I was in high school I thought it was the worst thing that could possibly happen. Today, I feel that I was blessed with recovery because my father had a problem and I knew that no matter what happened, there was always help out there for me. In my disease, I felt that I was trying to fill a black hole that could never be filled. Little did I know that hole was in my soul and that God could and would fill that hole in my sole if he were sought. I am grateful to be a soulfull survivor, today.

WELLGOS: Soul Survivor,God Grounder,Thy Will Be Doner,Gratitude Goosebumper

RAW: How taking responsibility ripples positively in the community Taking responsibility for my mistakes is not an easy thing to do. Especially, the big ones. I don’t want to share them with anyone. By keeping secrets, I am doomed to either make the same mistakes or relapse. Facing my mistakes and owning up to them is what I have to do to learn and grow in recovery. By taking responsibility and making amends to those I have harmed, I am teaching others that it is ok to admit that we are not perfect, that we make mistakes. One of the benefits of taking responsibility for my actions is that it is contagious. I notice that my husband is more apt to apologize and take responsibility for his mistakes because of my example. I also believe that it is an important lesson that I teach my children that I am not perfect and can take responsibility for my part in an argument or situation.
CATS: ACCOUNTABILITY / Own up,RESPONSIBILITY,VULNERABILITY / learning and mistakes
WELLGOS: Responsibility Rippler,ADMIT / accountability,VULNERABILITY / mistakes & learning

RAW: Shame is a tough feeling to shake. As an addict, I tend to be very self-critical, I want to be perfect. I don’t like to admit that I make some pretty huge mistakes. I made a mistake recently that I am still having difficulty shaking the shame and guilt that have overwhelmed me. When I make mistakes, I can beat myself up pretty well. I understand that I am a work in progress and I am not perfect. I can and will get better if I stop the self-harm and shaming behaviors. If I make a mistake, I can say, “Thank you God for another opportunity to learn from another mistake.” Some of the mistakes I make, can help others so they don’t have to make the same ones. By sharing my mistakes with other people, I can use my defects in a more positive way.
CATS: SHAME,MINDSET / imperfection & acceptance,VULNERABILITY / learning and mistakes
WELLGOS: The Deshamer,VULNERABILITY / mistakes & learning,Imperfections TBH,Blunder Blesser

RAW: I reach out to certain friends in recovery when I am struggling. People that know me and can support me without judging me for where I am. I have one really close friend in recovery who we are like program buddies and spend a lot of time sharing with one another. If one of us is struggling, the other reaches out to let them know that if they need anything we are available to help them when they are ready. It is nice to have people in my life to support me in my recovery. Having sponsors or mentors who are recovering is really helpful. I recently struggled with a problem, I did some writing and was really feeling agitated about it. I planned to spend ￼￼￼￼￼￼time with my current sponsor that evening, but called an old sponsor in the morning and shared about my problem with her. It was helpful to share with both of them and get their insights on my problem. Who is in your Sobriety SOS Support Team?

RAW: Staying sober is like a son of a bitch experience, but also, a sob story, has dual meanings On a good day, it seems sobriety is such a blessing in my life. When I am struggling and my disease comes out to play and I am in emotional turmoil, sobriety is an SOB, a pain in the neck and a thorn in my side. It’s not easy being clean and working through tough feelings. But, when you come out on the other side of a challenging issue without picking up, there are usually lessons and blessings associated with those challenges. These are the gifts of living a sober life.
CATS: SOBRIETY / costs & benefits,GRATITUDE / progress & growth,CONFIDENCE /  obstacles & challenge

RAW: Some people who don’t understand addiction often only understand the addict, they don’t really understand what a recovering addict is. In this way, they are more apt to stigmatize a food addict in a negative way and not understand what a recovering food addict even really looks like. I try to share my recovery with people in hopes that they will have a better understanding of addiction as well as recovery. People don’t know what they don’t know and the more we open up to people the greater the understanding will be.
CATS: LABELS / STIGMA,COMMUNITY / connection with others,WORTHINESS / connections & sharing
WELLGOS: Stigma Stigmatizer,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / share & learn,RELATIONSHIPS / Build connections & community

RAW: Death of a loved one can change the way we live. If we know someone who has had an addiction and been taken too soon, it is a wakeup call for our own recovery. Wake up calls alone will not keep us sober, we need to recommit to do the work to stay healthy and live a long productive life. I have experienced the loss of a close friend who suffered from addiction. For me, it was a wakeup call because I stopped and she kept going. God chose to save me. I have been blessed with a gift and I need to treat my recovery like a gift and not take it for granted.
CATS: CHANGE / motivations,MINDSET / Future sobriety,FREEDOM / tools & strategies
WELLGOS: Grave Trigger,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / motivations,Soul Survivor,The Dynamotivator

RAW: Abstinence... it was a hard thing for me to appreciate as a youth, largely because I didn't have the contrast of addiction to compare it to. Though it stood above all else, abstinence was not my choice – I just had nothing to abstain from. Once I screwed that up by doing drugs, abstinence certainly lost its place atop my clearheaded mind. Addiction took the throne, and soon, abstinence was the least important of all things - if I was abstinent, how could I get my fix? That's not a sustainable lifestyle, though. Things soon fell apart - I lost everything. Friends, family, shelter. As these things fell out of my grip, I came to realize that the only way I could restore them was through abstinence. Knowing this, I forced myself through detox - and, once again, I hold abstinence above all else.
CATS: SOBRIETY / costs & benefits,ABSTINENCE,INNER POWER / Self control & willpower,CHANGE / mental confidence
WELLGOS: Abstainer Amazer,Demon Dethroner ,COMMITMENT knitter / above all else,Sobriety Soulmater

RAW: It took a long time for me to sail through stormy addictions, battle shark-like cravings that struck relentlessly. After years of fighting my way through the rough seas of addiction, I found myself - at long last - clean, and sober. I'd steered my boat to the sea of Abstinence. I'd be foolish to not worry about relapse, though, so I'll need to anchor myself to abstinence. There's a few things I'm doing - I've mad some changes to my close friend group. While I'm still friends with people who use, I can't surround myself with them all the time. Complete honesty with myself and those arround me assures that if I look like I'm about to slip, somebody can catch me. I've been anchored here in abstinence for quite some time, and the water's great !
CATS: ABSTINENCE,COMMUNITY / healthy relationships,SOBRIETY / maintaining & will power
WELLGOS: COMMITMENT knitter / abstinence confidence,RELATIONSHIPS / Healthy & supportive,Inner Light Illuminator,Braverade

RAW: Accidents happen. I've known that since childhood. Sometimes, something happens for no good reason, and it sucks. Maybe someone spills their coffee on their carpet, maybe someone stubs their toe. In my case, I got addicted to drugs. I had to accept my addiction before I could accept it as an accident. For most of my dependency, I refused to accept I had a problem - that way, I had nothing to fix. I hadn't made any accidents, and I had no reason to apologize to myself. As I lost friends, I began to accept those as accidents - not my own fault. "He doesn't want to talk to me? What an idiot - all I did was accidentally say something mean." I 'accidentally' lost my house. When I 'accidentally' lost my girlfriend, I started thinking about how maybe I'd accidentally fallen into an unsustainable lifestyle. That acceptance allowed me to see all the damage I'd done, and take it upon myself. I had no desire to to drugs after this - the last few years had just been one, drawn-out accident. Through sober eyes, I accept that now - and I don't think I'll ever go back.
CATS: VULNERABILITY / learning and mistakes,ACCOUNTABILITY / damage confess,TRUTH / Inventory,CONFESSION
WELLGOS: RAW SOUL REVEALER / past mistakes,ADMIT / accountability,Responsibility Baby Stepper,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Inventory

RAW: I used to always hurt - anxiety, depression, and insecurity were a big part of my life, and by early teenagehood I'd admitted this much to myself. In a feeble attempt to stop the pain, I started using drugs. What really took strength to admit was not the emotional pain I felt as a teen - it was admitting that the Band-Aid I'd slapped over my problems was causing me more agony than ever before. Suddenly, the solution had become more of a problem than the problem had ever been - and it took me years to accept that. Taking that bandage off allowed the wounds to heal themselves, and now I'm happier than ever.
CATS: AGONY,INNER MASTERY / strength,TRUTH / Admit addiction
WELLGOS: Pain Abstainer,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Admit addiction,Whole Soul Healer,Inner Soul X-Rayer

RAW: Exploring for alternatives was what got me into drugs in the first place. I was curious to dive into a lifestyle that received so much criticism in the media, and had been talked down on so much. What was all the hype? I found out pretty quick, and this new 'alternative' became my everyday habit. I grew dependent to the point that I started losing friends. All but my closest friends had left me, and only when my girlfriend did, too, did I consider that maybe I needed to make a change. There weren't a whole lot of alternatives to explore at first - either I sit in my trashed apartment and wait for my landlord to come take me out with the garbage, or get off my ass and go to detox. I did the latter, and since going through that pain, I've got a whole world of alternatives to explore!
CATS: DEAD END,TRUTH / dark past,MINDSET / Future sobriety
WELLGOS: Dead End Defier ,Addiction AMF’r,Lost Benefit Lamenter,Inner Trash Trasher

RAW: I always thought myself to be a humble dude. I'd apologize all the time, even for things that I didn't have to. I just didn't want anyone to feel bad. I didn't apologize for getting into drugs, though - that was something I held dear for quite a few years. As I became more addicted, I became a worse person. I broke a lot of friendships off by being selfish, I lost a good relationship and housing situation. The whole world was falling apart in front of me, and only once I had nothing left did I decide... maybe I should go to detox. So, I did. After that, I was able to start making amends to the people I'd hurt.
CATS: AMENDS,RECONCILIATON,CONFESSION / damage & hurt
WELLGOS: Relationship Dedamager,The First Amender,CLOSET CONFESSOR / Face truths,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / admit & amends

RAW: Anger has never been one of my issues. I was a calm child, a calm preteen. My gateway drug was marijuana, which certainly accentuated this. I graduated quickly from smoking weed to smoking heroin, though - and heroin deprived my brain of a lot of positive emotion. I treated my friends like crap, but of course, I would never think I was doing so. They would tell me, try to arrest my anger and ration with me – but this only made me more angry. I needed someone to arrest my anger, and I couldn't do it myself. It took me the loss of everything important before I realized that the only way I could stop my problems was my stopping my addiction. Rehab would be my anger arrester. I bit the bullet and went through the painful process of detox. Each day the agony of withdrawal coursed through my body, I felt the residual anger depart with it. Upon my completion of detox, I found that I was, once again, anger free – and this time, much more appreciative of the positivity in my life.
CATS: ANGER,FREEDOM / tools & strategies,SOBRIETY / maintaining & will power,MINDSET / tolerate discomfort
WELLGOS: Lost Benefit Lamenter,Relationship Dedamager,Venom Vaporizer,NEW PATTERN PAINTER / admit & amends

RAW: It certainly wasn't autopilot that drove me to start using drugs. That was a carefully (mis)calculated decision, dotted with doubts and apprehension. I overrode my autopilot, but it came back with a vengeance once I developed an addiction. Similar to an average Joe's autopilot, I'd wake up, eat breakfast, go to work - but mine followed the more aggressive routine of: wake up sick, skip breakfast, go find money for drugs. That was the autopilot that coordinated my life for too many years. Eventually, I hit a point where it truly auto-stopped: I woke up one day, seeing the trashed apartment my girlfriend had just left me in, the empty parking space where my truck had sat, the vacant couches where friends could have been lounging. After all that, I finally noticed that I had a problem. That was the last day I used.
CATS: DEAD END,CHANGE / motivations,TRUTH / Admit addiction
WELLGOS: Autopilot Auto X’r,Dead End Deluder,Addiction AMF’r,The Dynamotivator,Bitter Truth Taster

RAW: Baby steps didn't only take me towards recovery - they also, in a perverse way, guided me into addiction.
